DIVISION 5. - PROSECUTING ATTORNEY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2012-15, adopted Aug. 21, 2012, added new provisions to the Code designated as Div. 5, §§ 2-91-2-98. Inasmuch as sections so numbered already exist, in order to avoid duplication and at the editor's discretion, said provisions have been redesignated as Div. 5, §§ 2-81-2-88. 

Sec. 2-81. - Intent. 
    In enacting this division, it is the intent of the city to comply with Georgia law, particularly O.C.G.A. Title 15, Ch. 18, Art. 5. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-82. - Establishment of office. 
    The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court is hereby established for the purpose of providing representation of the City of Union City in matters pertaining to ordinance violations of the city and state offenses enforceable in the municipal courts as allowed by Georgia law. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall be a part time position. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-83. - Qualifications. 
    Any person appointed as the prosecuting attorney for the Municipal Court of the City of Union City shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the trial and appellate courts of this state. Nothing in this division shall prevent the city from appointing the city attorney to be the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court, so long as all other requirements under the law are met. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-84. - Oath. 
    The prosecuting attorney for the Municipal Court of the City of Union City shall take and subscribe to the following oath: 
"I swear (or affirm) that I will well, faithfully, and impartially and without fear, favor, or affection discharge my duties as prosecuting attorney of the Municipal Court for the City of Union City." 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-85. - Term of office. 
    Unless otherwise provided by the Charter for the City of Union City, the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall serve a term of office of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-86. - Jurisdiction, duties, and authority. 
    The office of the prosecuting attorney of the Municipal Court of the City of Union City shall have the duty and authority to represent the city as defined by the City Charter and by state law, particularly as described in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-96. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-87. - Assistant prosecuting attorney. 
    The prosecuting attorney of the municipal court may appoint one or more assistant prosecuting attorneys whose appointment shall be ratified by the city council before becoming an assistant prosecuting attorney for the municipal court. Such assistant prosecuting attorney shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia or satisfy the provisions of the Third Year Practice Act, found in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-22. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 2-88. - Ratification. 
    This division shall ratify all actions that have been taken by the persons acting in the positions of the office of the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court to date as authorized by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Secs. 2-89, 2-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMPLOYEES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Personnel, Art. IV, Ch. 3. 

Sec. 2-91. - Federal old age and survivors insurance. 
(a)  It is the policy and purpose of the city to extend to the employees and officials of the city and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this article, the benefits of the system of federal old age and survivors insurance, as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, the State Enabling Act, and amendments thereto, upon the basis of applicable state and federal laws or regulations; authorizing and directing the mayor, or other chief executive officers, to execute agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia, for coverage of employees. Officials of the city shall appropriate and pay over for employers' contributions, administrative expenses and a guaranty fund, as provided by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, providing that the city shall keep records and make reports as required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. Any position, employee or official not authorized to be covered under applicable state or federal laws or regulations shall be excluded from this section. 
(b)  It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Social Security Administration to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this article, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, the State Enabling Act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of that policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(c)  The mayor, or other chief executive officer, of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia for coverage of employees and officials as provided for in subsection (a) above, to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner provided by law. 
(d)  Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose set out in subsection (a) above is authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(e)  There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employers' contributions and administrative expenses. Such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by that agency. 
(f)  The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or regulations. 
(g)  There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(h)  This section shall take effect upon its approval and publication as required by law. 
(Code 1976, § 3-501) 
Charter reference- Authority to establish retirement systems for municipal employees, § 1-103(44). 
Sec. 2-92. - Accident and health insurance for employees. 
(a)  Purpose. The city is desirous of providing a regular method whereby the city will make regular contributions to a trust fund, which contributions will be held for and devoted to the exclusive benefit of the city's participating employees and their beneficiaries, and shall be used to provide a plan of group life insurance and group accident and health insurance for the employees and their beneficiaries. 
(b)  Adoption. For the purpose of establishing a system for the city to provide group life insurance and group accident and health insurance to its employees there is hereby agreed and subscribed to that document entitled Insurance Trust Agreement, entered into in Atlanta, Fulton County, Georgia, on the 6th day of June 1972, by and between the Georgia Municipal Association, Inc., and the trustees as named and provided for in the agreement, and other participating member municipalities, and all terms, conditions, covenants and obligations as set forth therein. That insurance trust agreement is made a part hereof and incorporated herein by reference as fully as if the same were here set forth at length. 
(c)  Designation of trustee. The trustees named and provided for in the insurance trust agreement incorporated herein in subsection (b) above shall be the trustees of the trust fund established in the aforesaid insurance trust agreement. 
(d)  Selection of optional plans. Subject to all of the applicable terms and conditions set forth in the master insurance policy procured by the Georgia Municipal Association, Inc., pursuant to the aforementioned insurance trust agreement, the city herewith agrees and subscribes to that coverage for life insurance and accidental death and dismemberment insurance, designated in the insurance trust agreement as Plan "B." Also subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the aforesaid master insurance policy, the city further agrees and subscribes to the following insurance coverage as described in the insurance trust agreement. 
(e)  Acceptance; effective date. This section shall be accepted and approved in writing by the designated representative of the trustees named and provided for in the insurance trust agreement and the Georgia Municipal Association, Inc. This section shall take effect on January 1, 1973, and shall remain effective until repealed or replaced by a subsequent ordinance of the city governing authority. 
(Code 1976, § 3-502) 
Charter reference- Authority to provide for life, health and other insurance benefits for officers and employees, § 1-103(53). 
Sec. 2-93. - Vacations. 
    All employees of the city, except casual employees, who have been in the employ of the city for at least one (1) year, shall be entitled to one (1) week's vacation with pay. All employees, except casual employees, who have been in the employ of the city for two (2) or more years, shall be entitled to two (2) weeks' vacation with pay. 
(Code 1976, § 3-503) 
Sec. 2-94. - Employee drug policy. 
(a)  Purpose. The mayor and council finds that the manufacture, distribution, sale, use, or possession of controlled substances, marijuana, and other dangerous drugs in an unlawful manner is a serious threat to the public health, safety, and welfare. The mayor and council further finds that the use of alcohol during or prior to working hours is prohibited where alcohol can be measured at the level of .02 grams during working hours, said level being presumptively adverse to the safety of the workplace. It is declared to be a primary purpose and goal of this city, and of all of its public officials and employees to take all reasonable steps possible to eradicate the unlawful manufacture, distribution, sale, use, and possession of controlled substances, marijuana, and other dangerous drugs; and further to take all reasonable steps to eradicate the use of alcohol where a level of .02 grams exists, such level adversely affecting the safety of the workplace. With this purpose in mind, the mayor and council declares that its work force must be absolutely free of any person who would knowingly manufacture, distribute, sell, use, or possess a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug in an unlawful manner; and from any person whose use of alcohol results in a level of .02 grams during working hours. For this reason, and pursuant to Chapter 23 of Title 45 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, the mayor and council enacts this section. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section the term: 
    City means Union City, Georgia. 
    City employee means any person employed by the city. 
    Controlled substance means any drug, substance, or immediate precursor included in Schedules I through V of O.C.G.A. sections 16-13-25 through 16-13-29 and Schedules I through V of 21 Code of Federal Regulations Part 1308. 
    Convicted or conviction refers to a final conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction or the acceptance of a plea of guilty. 
    Criminal drug statute means any criminal statute involving the manufacture, sale, distribution, dispensation, use, or possession of any controlled substance or marijuana. 
    Dangerous drug means any drug or substance defined as such under O.C.G.A. section 16-13-71. 
    Marijuana means all parts of the plant of the genus Cannabis, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant, and shall include the completely defoliated mature stalks of such plant, or fiber produced from such stalks. 
    Safety sensitive employees means all employees of Union City with the exception of the following positions: Cashier clerk; accounts technician; permit/tax/license technician; accounts payable technician; receptionist; part-time court clerk assistant; and part-time records clerk. 
    Under the influence of drugs/alcohol means testing positive for the presence of illegal drugs or a blood alcohol test result of .02 grams or more. 
(c)  Violation. It shall be a violation of this policy for any city employee to be under the influence of a controlled substance or alcohol while on the work premises or elsewhere as a result of job requirements during working hours while the employee is at work. Any city employee in possession of, selling, distributing, trafficking or manufacturing any controlled substance shall be in violation of this policy. 
(d)  Prescription drugs. Any city employee under his/her doctor's orders to take prescription medication, and who is requested to undergo drug testing, shall notify his/her immediate supervisor, prior to the testing, if that employee is currently taking the prescribed medication. Any person who has been offered employment with the city in a position that has been designated as high risk, and is under his/her doctor's orders to take prescription medication, and is currently taking the prescribed medication, shall notify the human resources director, prior to the mandatory preemployment testing. 
(e)  Random drug testing. Due to the potential serious consequences of a city employee attempting to perform his/her job functions while under the influence of drugs or alcohol, all safety sensitive city employees are subject to random drug/alcohol testing. Nonsensitive city employees, as listed in (a) above, under the definition for "safety sensitive employees", may also volunteer to participate in the random drug testing. Volunteer participation in the random drug testing may be accomplished by the nonsensitive employee submitting a signed and notarized certificate to their department head, who will approve the voluntary participation in writing and forward the completed certificate to the human resources director for enclosure in the employee's personnel folder. All persons who have been offered employment with the city must undergo drug/alcohol testing as a precondition to employment. All employees are subject to the same disciplinary measures contained in this article for their refusal to undergo the testing. 
(f)  Reasonable suspicion. Any city employee who demonstrates an unexplained inability to perform his/her normal job functions safely or productively, and/or exhibits characteristics consistent with the use of a controlled substance or alcohol (e.g., slurred speech, unsteady gait, etc.) will be required to undergo a drug/alcohol test to determine whether or not a violation of this policy has occurred. Whenever any supervisor detects any evidence of alcohol, drugs or controlled substances in the work place, such evidence shall constitute reasonable suspicion that an employee is in violation of this policy. 
(g)  Procedures for reasonable suspicion drug/alcohol testing. Any supervisor who has reason to believe an employee is under the influence of drugs/alcohol, in a nonemergency situation, shall contact the city administrator, or his/her designee, to obtain approval prior to requesting the employee to undergo the testing. In a nonemergency situation, one (1) or more additional supervisors shall observe the employee to corroborate that reasonable suspicion exists warranting a drug/alcohol test. 
    The employee shall be requested by the supervisor to undergo a drug/alcohol test. If the employee should refuse to submit to the testing, disciplinary measures shall be taken against the employee, ranging from a minimum five-day suspension from work without pay up to and including termination, for refusing to submit to the testing and for insubordination. The next time a supervisor requests the employee to undergo a drug/alcohol test based upon the supervisor's suspicion that the employee is under the influence of drugs/alcohol, if the employee should refuse to submit to the testing the employee will be terminated. 
    The employee, after consenting to the testing, shall be transported by the city to the testing facility. Following the test, the employee shall be suspended with pay pending an investigation and the test results. If the test results are positive, the employee will be afforded an opportunity to explain. If no justifiable explanation exists, disciplinary action will be taken up to and including termination. If the test is negative, the supervisor will explain this to the employee and the employee will be assured that this matter has been concluded and nothing will be placed in the employee's personnel file. The employee will then immediately assume his/her job responsibilities. 
(h)  Confidential information. Information concerning suspected controlled substance use and testing results shall be placed in locked files separate from the routine personnel files. Such information shall be communicated only to those individuals who need to know the information in order to perform their job functions. 
(i)  Suspension or termination of city employee convicted of drug offense. 
(1)  Any city employee who is convicted for the first time, under the laws of this state, the United States, or any other state, of any criminal offense involving the manufacture, distribution, sale, or possession of a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug shall be subject to disciplinary action, ranging from a minimum five-day suspension from work without pay up to and including termination. Any such employee not terminated shall be required to complete a drug abuse treatment and education program licensed under O.C.G.A. Chapter 5 of Title 26. 
(2)  Any city employee who is convicted for a second or subsequent time, under the laws of this state, the United States, or any other state, of any criminal offense involving the manufacture, distribution, sale, or possession of a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug shall be terminated from his/her employment. 
(j)  Ineligibility for city employment of person convicted of drug offense. 
(1)  Any person who has been convicted for the first time, under the laws of this state, the United States, or any other state, of any criminal offense involving the manufacture, distribution, sale, use or possession of a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug shall be ineligible for any city employment for a period of twelve (12) months from the date of conviction. 
(2)  Any person who has been convicted two (2) or more times, under the laws of this state, the United States, or any other state, of any criminal offense involving the manufacture, distribution, sale, or possession of a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug shall be ineligible for any city employment for a period of five (5) years from the most recent date of conviction. 
(k)  Last chance policy. If, prior to an arrest for an offense involving a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug, a city employee notifies the city that the employee illegally uses a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug and is receiving or agrees to receive treatment under a drug abuse treatment and education program licensed under O.C.G.A. Chapter 5 of Title 26 and approved by the city, the employee shall be entitled to maintain city employment for up to one (1) year as long as the employee follows the treatment plan. During this period, the city employee shall not be separated from city employment solely on the basis of the employee's drug dependence, but the employee's work activities may be restructured if practicable to protect persons or property. 
    No statement made by an employee to a supervisor of the city employee or other person in order to comply with this section shall be admissible in any civil, administrative, or criminal proceeding as evidence against the city employee. The rights granted by this code section shall be available to a city employee only once during a five-year period and shall not apply to any city employee who has refused to be tested or who has tested positive for a controlled substance, marijuana, or a dangerous drug. 
(Ord. No. 00-02, §§ 1-11, 1-18-00; Ord. No. 2001-05, §§ 1, 2, 3-20-01) 
Secs. 2-95-2-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DEPARTMENTS[9]

DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC WORKS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 15. 

Sec. 2-121. - Composition. 
    The department of public works shall consist of the superintendent of public works, who shall be the head of the department, and all officers and employees assigned thereto by the mayor or council. 
(Code 1976, § 3-601) 
Sec. 2-122. - Appointment of superintendent. 
    The superintendent of public works shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, and he shall have control and supervision over all officers and employees assigned to the department, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 3-601) 
Sec. 2-123. - Duties of superintendent. 
    The superintendent of public works shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To provide for and supervise the care, maintenance, construction and extension of all streets, sidewalks, street gutters and drains, alleys and public ways; 
(2)  To have charge of and be responsible for the care, maintenance and operation of the city water distribution system, the sanitary sewer system and disposal plant, and the streetlighting system; 
(3)  To have charge of and supervision over all public property of the city, including all parks, parkways, playgrounds, municipal cemeteries, buildings and utilities not assigned to some other department or officer; 
(4)  To have charge of the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse; 
(5)  To have charge of and be responsible for the condition of all motor vehicles and other equipment of the city, and all buildings or places in which the same are housed or kept, except those of the police and fire departments; 
(6)  To be the custodian of all tools, equipment and other personal property belonging to the city and not assigned to the care of any other public office of the city; and 
(7)  To perform such additional duties as may be assigned to him from time to time by the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 3-601) 
Secs. 2-124-2-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - POLICE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment of chief of police, § 4-204(2). 

Sec. 2-136. - Generally. 
(a)  Composition. The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other officers and personnel as the mayor and council shall prescribe. 
(b)  Rank. Following the police chief in rank shall be the captain, the lieutenants, sergeants, and the policemen, in order of seniority in each group. 
(c)  Police chief: 
(1)  Appointment and powers. The police chief shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall be the chief executive officer of the police department, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council. In the exercise of his duties, the police chief shall have the power to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. 
(2)  Duties. The police chief shall have the following duties: 
a.  To attend all meetings of the city council and all trials before the recorder's court; 
b.  To see to the proper service of all summonses, subpoenas, citations, executions, attachments and rules of the city council; 
c.  To see to the collection of all fines and costs imposed by the recorder's court; 
d.  To see that the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city and all statutes applicable therein are faithfully enforced; 
e.  To preserve the public peace, prevent infractions of the law and arrest any violators thereof; 
f.  To protect the rights of persons and property; 
g.  To oversee the conduct of the officers and men of the police force, and to be held strictly responsible for such conduct and for the general good order of the department; 
h.  To keep adequate records of all personnel and equipment of the department, including a log of all questions, activities and investigations; 
i.  To submit a monthly report to the city council outlining the number and type of arrests for state offenses, the number and type of cases involving violations of municipal ordinances, and the number of arrests made and cases reported by each police officer; 
j.  To submit monthly to the state department of public safety the Uniform Crime Report prescribed by state law; and 
k.  To discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the mayor or council. 
(3)  Resignation, removal, death or disability. In the event of resignation, removal, death or disability of the police chief, the officer next in rank shall perform the duties of the chief until removal of such disability or until a successor has been duly appointed. 
(d)  Police officers: 
(1)  Qualifications. Any person employed by the city as a police officer shall have the following qualifications: 
a.  Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
b.  Be a citizen of the United States; 
c.  Have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent; 
d.  Not have been convicted, by any state or by the federal government, of any crime, the punishment for which could have been imprisonment in a federal or state prison or institution; nor shall he have been convicted of sufficient misdemeanors to establish a pattern of disregard for the law; 
e.  Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state, and national fingerprint files to disclose any criminal record; 
f.  Possess good moral character as determined by investigation under procedures established by the state peace officers standards and training council; 
g.  Have an oral interview with the mayor and city council to determine such things as the applicant's appearance, background and ability to communicate; 
h.  Be found, after examination by a licensed physician or surgeon, to be free from any physical, emotional or mental conditions which might adversely affect his exercising the powers or duties of a police officer; and 
i.  Complete satisfactorily at least a basic course of two hundred forty (240) hours of instruction within twelve (12) months of the date of his appointment as a police officer, except that an extension may be granted by the state peace officers standards and training council on account of illness, injury, military service or other reasons deemed sufficient by that council. 
(2)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to acquire a full knowledge of and to enforce all of the ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable therein, to become familiar with the rules and regulations established by the police chief concerning the discipline, good order, proper conduct, care and management of the police department, and to respect and obey all orders of the police chief not in conflict with the law or ordinances of the city. 
(3)  Conduct. Every member of the police department shall conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times and shall avoid the use of unnecessary force. Prohibited conduct shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Absence from regular hours of duty without permission; 
b.  Sleeping on duty; 
c.  Insubordination or disobedience of orders; 
d.  Drinking any malt or intoxicating beverage while on duty or in uniform; 
e.  Wilful maltreatment of any person or prisoner; 
f.  Using profane language; 
g.  Giving out or releasing any information covering the affairs, business or operation of the police department without the consent of the police chief; 
h.  Receiving or accepting a reward from any person for any services rendered in the line of duty; 
i.  Accepting bribes of money, gifts or other articles of apparent or actual value, or accepting any fee, reward or gift of any kind from a person arrested or from any friend in his behalf while he is in custody or after his release or discharge; or 
j.  Active participation in any political campaign to the neglect of his official duty. 
(4)  Penalties for improper conduct. Any police officer violating the rules or regulations of the police department or of this Code, upon conviction therefor by the city council, after due notice and hearing, or upon the plea of guilty, shall be reprimanded, fined, suspended or dismissed by the city council. Any one (1) or more of these penalties may be imposed in the discretion of the city council. 
(e)  Arms and uniforms. Each officer and member of the police department shall be furnished with such uniforms, arms and police equipment as provided for by the city council. Uniforms shall be kept clean and pressed and shall be worn on duty at all times, unless otherwise ordered by a superior officer. The equipment, arms and uniforms furnished by the city shall be and always remain the property of the city and shall be, when a change is ordered or on retirement from office, returned to the city. The members of the department shall be liable for any loss or careless destruction of or damage to their arms and uniforms. 
(f)  Arrests. Police officers of the city may make arrests for violations of municipal ordinances and state laws when such violations are committed in their presence or when they have obtained a valid arrest warrant from the judge of the city court or from some other proper authority. In exercising such power of arrest, all police officers shall see that all necessary warnings are given to the accused as required by law. 
(g)  Entering private dwellings. No police officer shall enter a private dwelling without a search or arrest warrant unless he is in pursuit of a fugitive who the officer has personal knowledge or probable cause to believe has committed or attempted to commit a felony. 
(h)  Disposition of stolen, abandoned, or impounded property: 
(1)  All personal property which comes into the custody of the police department, where the property has been stolen or impounded or where the ownership is unknown, shall be held for a period of forty-five (45) days awaiting claim by its owner. The owner of the property, upon proving ownership and paying all expenses and costs, including reasonable charges for storage, shall have the right to have such property returned to him. 
(2)  If after the expiration of forty-five (45) days the property is unclaimed, the chief of police shall advertise the property for sale in the newspaper in which the city's legal advertisements are printed. Such advertising shall take place at least seven (7) days before the date set for the sale and shall give a description of the property to be sold and specify the time and place of sale. If the property is still unclaimed by the time of the sale, it shall be sold as advertised and the proceeds shall be placed in the city treasury. 
(Code 1976, § 3-602) 
Sec. 2-137. - 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. 
(a)  Imposition. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2, there is hereby imposed a prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charge as defined by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(a)(4) upon every prepaid wireless retail transaction occurring within the jurisdiction of the public service answering point in the amount of seventy-five cents ($0.75). 
(b)  Collection. Prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charges collected by sellers shall be remitted to the Commissioner of the Department of Revenue at the times and in the manner provided by O.C.G.A. Tit. 48, Ch. 8 with respect to the sales and use tax imposed on prepaid wireless calling service. 
(c)  Administrative provisions. The Clerk of the City of Union City is hereby directed to file with the state revenue commissioner a certified copy of this ordinance [from which this section derives] and amendments thereto in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(l), by December 31, 2011. 
(d)  Depositing of funds; use of funds. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(5), funds received by this city from charges imposed by this section shall be deposited in the emergency telephone system fund maintained by this city pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(d)(2) and kept separate from general revenue of the jurisdiction. All such funds shall be used exclusively for the purposes authorized by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(f). 
(Ord. No. 2011-14, § 1, 9-20-11) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2011-14, adopted Sept. 20, 2011, states "This ordinance [section] shall become effective on January 1, 2012. 
Sec. 2-138. - Schedule of fees. 
    The police chief shall be authorized to collect fees for the provision of certain services by the police department and its personnel. Said fees shall be as set forth in a schedule of fees duly adopted by the mayor and council for the City of Union City. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1, 4-21-15) 
Secs. 2-139-2-149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SOUTH FULTON MUNICIPAL REGIONAL JAIL DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-150. - Generally. 
(a)  Composition. The jail shall consist of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief and such other officers and personnel as the mayor and council shall prescribe. 
(b)  Rank. Following the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief in rank shall be the assistant chief. 
(c)  South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief. 
(1)  Appointment and powers. The South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall be the chief executive officer of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail, subject always to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council. In the exercise of his duties, the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief shall have the powers to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. 
(2)  Duties. The South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief shall have the following duties: 
a.  To attend all meetings of the city council and South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Authority; 
b.  To establish necessary rules and regulations concerning conduct, care, and management of the department and inmates, subject to the approval of the mayor and council; 
c.  To oversee the conduct of the jailers and other employees of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department, and to be held strictly responsible for such conduct and for the general good of the department; 
d.  To keep adequate records of all personnel, equipment, and inmates in the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department, including incident reports of all questions, activities, and investigations; and 
e.  To discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the mayor and council. 
(3)  Resignation, removal, death or disability. In the event of resignation, removal, death or disability of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief, the employee next in rank in the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall perform the duties of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief until removal of said chief's disability or until a successor has been duly appointed by the mayor and council. 
(d)  Jailers. 
(1)  Qualifications. Any person employed by the city as a jailer shall have the following qualifications: 
a.  Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
b.  Be a citizen of the United States; 
c.  Have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent; 
d.  Not have been convicted, by any state or by the federal government, of any felony; nor shall he have been convicted of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
e.  Be fingerprinted and a search made of local, state, and national fingerprint files to disclose any criminal record; 
f.  Possess good moral character as determined by investigation under procedures established by the Georgia Peace Officers Standards and Training Council (POST); 
g.  Be found, after examination by a licensed physician or surgeon, to be free from any physical, emotional or mental conditions which might adversely affect his exercise of power or commission of his/her duties as a jailer; and 
h.  Complete satisfactorily at least a basic training course of eighty (80) hours of instruction within six (6) months of the date of his appointment as a jailer. 
(2)  Duties. It shall be the duty of a jailer of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail to acquire a full knowledge of, observe, and to enforce the rules and regulations established by the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief, or any other appropriate federal, state, or city authority concerning the good order, proper conduct, care and management of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail; and to acquire full knowledge of, observe and enforce the rules and regulations established by the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief or any other appropriate federal, state, or city authority governing the interactions of staff and inmates including, but not limited to, limits on the use of force, physical or verbal contact with current and former inmates, and the proper handling of inmates and the property thereof; and to respect and obey all orders of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief not in conflict with the law or ordinances of the city. 
(3)  Conduct. Every member of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times and shall not use unnecessary force. Prohibited conduct shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Absence from regular hours of duty without permission; 
b.  Sleeping on duty; 
c.  Insubordination; 
d.  Drinking any malt or intoxicating beverage while on duty or in uniform; 
e.  Willful maltreatment of any person or inmate; 
f.  Using profane language; 
g.  Giving out or releasing any information covering the affairs, business or operation of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department without the consent of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Chief; 
h.  Receiving or accepting a reward from any person for any services rendered in the line of duty; 
i.  Accepting bribes of money, gifts or other articles of apparent or actual value, or accepting any fee, reward or gift of any kind from a person held at the jail of from any friend on an inmate's behalf while he/she is in custody or after his/her release or discharge; or 
j.  Active participation in any political campaign to the neglect of his official duty. 
(e)  Arms and uniforms. Each jailer and member of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Department shall be furnished with such uniforms, arms and equipment as specified by the jail chief. Uniforms shall be kept clean and pressed and shall be worn on duty at all times, unless otherwise ordered by a superior. The equipment, arms and uniforms furnished by the city shall be and always will remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the city upon demand, termination of the jailer, retirement of the jailer, a change of equipment or uniform, or similar event. 
(f)  [Duty regarding familiarity with equipment and apparatus.] Each jailer and member of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall have a duty to become familiar with and proficient in handling all jail equipment and apparatus necessary to the discharge of his/her duties, including any arms and/or uniforms. 
(g)  Disposition of stolen, abandoned, or impounded property. 
(1)  All personal property which comes into the custody of the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall be securely held by the department and released into the custody of the prisoner whom owns the property or to a person designated in writing by said prisoner upon the release of said prisoner. If property exists whose owner is unknown or cannot be located, it shall be securely held for a period of ninety (90) days awaiting claim by its owner. The owner of the property, upon proving ownership and paying any expenses and costs, including reasonable charges for storage, shall have the right to have such property returned to him. 
(2)  If after the expiration of ninety (90) days the property is unclaimed, the South Fulton Municipal Regional Jail Department shall forward the property to the police chief. The police chief shall advertise the property for sale in the newspaper in which the City's legal advertisements are printed. Such advertising shall take place at least seven (7) days before the date set out for the sale and shall give a description of the property to be sold and specify the time and place of sale. If the property is still unclaimed by the time of the sale, it shall be sold as advertised and the proceeds shall be placed in the city treasury. 
(Ord. No. 2007-10, § 1, 4-17-07) 
Secs. 2-151-2-169. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-170. - Schedule of fines and fees.

In addition, the municipal court is authorized to assess fees for certain services and purposes, with said fees set forth in a schedule of fees duly adopted by the mayor and council for the City of Union City. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 2, 4-21-15) 
Secs. 2-171-2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 89-21, adopted Oct. 3, 1989, did not expressly amend the Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-8 as Art. VI, §§ 2-201-2-208, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Police department, § 2-136. 

Sec. 2-201. - Law enforcement alliance. 
    City of Union City agrees to aid and assist other municipalities and counties adopting an ordinance identical hereto in its substantive provisions and approved by Union City Chief of Police, in such law enforcement investigations and activities as may be authorized pursuant to procedures herein set forth. Investigations and activities so authorized shall entail to the participating municipalities and counties the respective rights, status and obligations herein defined, as fully as if set forth by contract. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 1, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-202. - Assistance request. 
    Requests for assistance shall be initiated by the chief of police or other chief law enforcement officer of the requesting municipality or county to the chief of police or other chief enforcement officer of each municipality or county whose assistance is requested, accompanied by oral or written statement of his enforcement objective. Such statement shall include at a minimum, the purpose, proposed duration; manpower and equipment requirements; name and employing entity of the officer in charge of such investigation or activity; insofar as practicable, the names of persons and officers reasonably expected to participate and the nature of assistance requested. Such investigation and/or activity shall be conclusively presumed to be authorized by the municipality or county employing the requesting officer. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 2, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-203. - Response to request. 
    The chief of police or other chief law enforcement officer of the municipality or county receiving such request for assistance shall honor or decline such request promptly on receipt and shall not unreasonably decline to assist. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 3, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-204. - Manner of assistance. 
    Requests may be honored for manpower or equipment. Officers detailed responsive to a request shall be deemed attached for command purposes to the chief of police or other chief law enforcement officer of the requesting municipality or county solely for the projected duration of the investigation or activity as set forth in the requesting municipality's or county's statement of the enforcement objective, unless extended by consent of the requesting municipality or county and the assisting municipality or county through their respective chiefs of police or chief law enforcement officers. 
(a)  Qualifications and powers of officers detailed and attached. Officers detailed by an assisting municipality or county shall be certified pursuant to the Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act; grade and experience requested; prior to commencing duties pursuant to the detail and attachment; shall be sworn as law enforcement officers of the requesting municipality or county and shall be vested while attached with the same powers, duties and authority as the requesting municipality's or county's permanent law enforcement officers. 
(b)  Equipment loans. Detail of an officer by an assisting municipality or county shall imply authority to such officer to use while attached elsewhere, such clothing, firearms, and other equipment assigned to and normally used by such officer during duty with the assisting municipality or county. Other specific items of equipment may be loaned by an assisting municipality or county pursuant to a request, subject to the following requirements and conditions: 
(1)  Concurrently, an officer of the assisting municipality or county who will be capable of operating or safeguarding and accounting for such equipment, shall be attached to the requesting municipality or county; 
(2)  The chief of police or other law enforcement officer of the requesting municipality or county shall receive a receipt for such equipment when it enters his jurisdiction; 
(3)  The requesting municipality or county shall, promptly on request, return such equipment in as good condition, normal wear and tear alone except, as when received; and 
(4)  Equipment loaned pursuant hereto and lost, destroyed, or damaged, shall be promptly replaced or repaired at the requesting municipality's or county's expense. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 4, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-205. - Ad hoc withdrawal. 
    Nothing herein shall prohibit unilateral withdrawal of men or equipment at any time by an assisting municipality or county, but withdrawal shall be made with full regard and due care for the integrity of the investigation or activity underway; in no event shall withdrawal occur with the initial projected duration of an assisted investigation, except by reason of compelling necessity within the assisting municipality or county. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 5, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-206. - Liability. 
    Notwithstanding detail of an officer from an assisting municipality or county, and his attachment to a requesting municipality or county, ultimate authority over such officer and responsibility for such officer's acts, omissions and negligence shall remain with the municipality or county employing such officer. Each municipality or county assisting another pursuant to this article shall save and hold the requesting municipality or county harmless and indemnify such municipality or county as against all loss, liability and expense arising solely and proximately from acts, omissions and negligence of such officer while engaged in an assisted investigation or activity authorized pursuant hereto. It is provided, however, that nothing herein shall bar or hinder assertion by the assisting municipality or county of any defenses, counter-claims or cross-claims consistent with provisions of this article, including without limitation, the defenses of denial or liability in whole or in part, assertion of liability of another in whole or in part, and the assertion of the doctrines of accident, respondent superior, non-agency and comparative negligence. The requesting municipality or county assumes full responsibility for the use, operation, safekeeping of equipment loaned by a municipality or county pursuant to request as herein provided, for and during the period requested, or retained after expiration of such period, and shall save and hold the assisting municipality or county harmless as against loss, liability and expense arising out of use, operation or possession of such equipment by the requesting municipality or county or by an officer attached to the requesting municipality, or county as herein provided, except while used, operated or possessed by an officer employed by the assisting municipality or county. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 6, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-207. - Participating municipality defined. 
    A "participating municipality or county" as contemplated herein shall be deemed to mean such Georgia municipality or county within a fifty-mile radius of the City of Union City as whose governing authority shall at anytime hereafter while this ordinance is of force and effect, adopt an ordinance identical hereto in its substantive provisions, and approved by the Union City Chief of Police. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 7, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 2-208. - Termination; effect of termination. 
    A participating municipality or county may terminate its participation hereunder at any time by repeal of its ordinance qualifying it for such participation. Such repeal and termination, however, shall not affect its obligations arising during and out of its prior participation hereunder, either contractual or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 89-21, § 8, 10-3-89) 
Secs. 2-209-2-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BOARD, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-221-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - UNION CITY PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 92-6, enacted March 3, 1992, added provisions designated as a new Ch. 16 to the Code. For purposes of classification, such provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 2, Art. VII, Div. 2, §§ 2-241-2-244 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-241. - Created. 
    In order to make recommendations to the Mayor and Council as to the formulation, funding, and supervision of recreational programs and opportunities for citizens of all age groups, including senior citizens, handicapped citizens, and underprivileged youths, the Union City Parks and Recreation Committee, hereinafter referred to as the "Recreation Committee" or "committee", is hereby created and established. The Recreation Committee shall be organized and empowered as set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 92-6, § 1, 3-3-92) 
Sec. 2-242. - Organization. 
(a)  Membership. The recreation committee shall consist of five (5) members, who shall be residents of the city appointed by the mayor and council of the city. 
(b)  Terms. The terms of the members shall be for two (2) years, except that in the appointment of the first recreation committee under the terms of this section, two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, and three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. The terms of all members shall begin on the first day of the month following the month in which the committee is activated. All members of the committee shall, if necessary, hold over until their successors are appointed and qualified. The successors shall be appointed in the same manner as the initial members in the month immediately preceding the expiration of the members' respective terms of office. Any member of the committee may be re-selected and re-appointed to serve a succeeding term. 
(c)  Vacancies. A vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and council of the city. The mayor and council shall also have the power to remove any member of the committee if that member is found to be unsatisfactory in fulfilling the purpose of the committee or in performing his/her duties. 
(d)  Compensation. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties if such expenses are approved by the city administrator. 
(e)  Quorum. Three (3) members of the committee shall constitute a quorum. A vacancy on the committee shall not impair the right of the quorum to exercise all the rights and perform all the duties of the committee. 
(Ord. No. 92-6, § 2, 3-3-92) 
Sec. 2-243. - Election of chairperson; bylaws; miscellaneous. 
    The recreation committee shall elect a chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be for one (1) year with eligibility for re-election. The committee shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the municipality. The committee shall devise its own bylaws, which shall be supplied to the city administrator. The committee shall report directly to the city administrator. Any incidental expenditures of the committee shall be within the amounts appropriated for such purpose by the mayor and council of the city. 
(Ord. No. 92-6, § 3, 3-3-92) 
Sec. 2-244. - Purpose. 
    The recreation committee is created strictly for the purpose of making recommendations on various recreation programs and activities to the mayor and council, and to advise the city administrator of various recreational issues. This chapter in no way is to be construed as creating a recreation authority. 
(Ord. No. 92-6, § 4, 3-3-92) 
Secs. 2-245-2-259. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 2-260. - Regulations continued in effect. 
    All ordinances, resolutions, motions and orders pertaining to civil defense, emergency management and disaster relief, which are not in conflict with this article, are continued in full force and effect. Such ordinances, etc., are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 2-261. - Emergency management and response powers. 
(a)  Declaration of local emergency. 
(1)  Grant of authority. In the event of an actual or threatened occurrence of a disaster or emergency, which may result in the large-scale loss of life, injury, property damage or destruction or in the major disruption of routine community affairs, business or governmental operations in the city and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by federal, state and local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources, the mayor may declare a local emergency for the City of Union City. The form of the declaration shall be similar to that provided in subsection (b) of this Code section. 
(2)  Request for state assistance. Consistent with a declaration of local emergency, the mayor may request the governor to provide assistance, provided that the disaster or emergency is beyond the capacity of the city to meet adequately and state assistance is necessary to supplement local efforts to save lives and protect property, public health and safety, or to avert or lessen the threat of a disaster. 
(3)  Continuance. The declaration of local emergency shall continue until the mayor finds that emergency conditions no longer exist, at which time, the mayor shall execute and file with the city clerk a document marking the end of the state of emergency. No state of local emergency shall continue for longer than thirty (30) days, unless renewed by the mayor. The city governing authority may, by resolution and in accordance with the city charter, end a state of local emergency at any time. 
(4)  Effect of declaration of local emergency. 
a.  Activation of emergency operations plan. A declaration of emergency by the governor or a declaration of local emergency by the mayor shall automatically activate the local emergency operations plan and shall be authority for the deployment of personnel and use of any forces to which the plan applies and for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, materials, and facilities assembled, stockpiled or arranged to be made available pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act or any other laws applicable to emergencies or disasters. 
1.  The fire chief and/or his/her designees shall have the legal authority to exercise the powers and discharge the duties conferred by law, including the implementation of the applicable local emergency operations plan, coordination of the emergency responses of public and private agencies and organizations, coordination of recovery efforts with county, state and federal officials, and inspection of emergency or disaster sites. 
2.  In responding to the emergency and conducting necessary and appropriate survey of the damages caused by the emergency, the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) or his/her designee is authorized to enter at a reasonable time upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of evaluating sites involved with emergency management functions to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
3.  The fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) is authorized to execute a right of entry and/or agreement to use property for these purposes on behalf of the city; however, any such document shall be later presented for ratification by the city governing authority. 
4.  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the city who requests entry for purposes of evaluating sites involved with emergency management functions to protect the health, safety, or welfare of the public, and who presents appropriate credentials. Nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while that individual is in the process of carrying out his or her official duties. 
b.  Emergency powers. Following a declaration of emergency and during the continuance of such state of emergency, the mayor is authorized to implement local emergency measures to protect life and property or to bring the emergency situation under control. In exercising this authority, the mayor may cause to become effective any of the sections of this chapter as appropriate. If any of these sections is included in a declaration of local emergency, the same shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be in effect until the declaration of local emergency has terminated. 
c.  Authority to waive procedures and fees. Pursuant to a declaration of emergency, the city governing authority is authorized to cause to be effective any of the subsections of section 2-263 of this chapter as appropriate. The implementation of such subsections shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
d.  Additional emergency powers. The fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) shall have and may exercise for such period as the declared emergency exists or continues, the following additional emergency powers: 
1.  To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area, for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response or recovery; 
2.  To prescribe routes, modes of transportation and destinations in connection with evacuation; 
3.  To make provision for the availability and use of temporary emergency housing, emergency shelters and/or emergency medical shelters; 
4.  To transfer the direction, personnel or functions of any city departments and agencies or units thereof for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency services; 
5.  To utilize all available resources of the city and subordinate agencies over which the city has budgetary control as reasonably necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster; 
6.  To utilize public property when necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster or when there is compelling necessity for the protection of lives, health and welfare; and/or the property of citizens; 
7.  To suspend any law, code provision or regulation prescribing the procedures for conduct of city business, or the orders, rules or regulations of any city agency, if strict compliance with any ordinance, resolution, order, rule or regulation would in any way prevent, hinder or delay necessary action in coping with the emergency or disaster, provided that such suspension shall provide for the minimum deviation from the requirements under the circumstances and further provided that, when practicable, specialists shall be assigned to avoid adverse effects resulting from such suspension; 
8.  To provide benefits to citizens upon execution of an intergovernmental agreement for grants to meet disaster-related necessary expenses or serious needs of individuals or families adversely affected by an emergency or disaster in cases where the individuals or families are unable to meet the expenses or needs from other means, provided that such grants are authorized only when matching state or federal funds are available for such purposes; 
9.  To perform and exercise such other functions, powers and duties as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian population, including individuals with household pets and service animals prior to, during, and following a major disaster or emergency. 
(b)  Form of declaration. Upon the declaration of local emergency, an official "Declaration of Local Emergency," in substantially the same form set forth below, shall be signed and filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be communicated to the citizens of the affected area using the most effective and efficient means available. The declaration shall state the nature of the emergency or disaster, the conditions that require the declaration and any sections of this chapter which shall be in effect. 
"DECLARATION OF LOCAL EMERGENCY 
WHEREAS, the City of Union City, Georgia has experienced an event of critical significance as a result of [DESCRIPTION OF EVENT] on [DATE]; and 
WHEREAS, in the judgment of the Mayor of the City of Union City, there exist emergency circumstances located in [DESCRIBE GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION] requiring extraordinary and immediate corrective actions for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Union City, including individuals with household pets and service animals; and 
WHEREAS, to prevent or minimize injury to people and damage to property resulting from this event; 
NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to the authority vested in me by local and state law; 
IT IS HEREBY DECLARED that a local state of emergency exists and shall continue until the conditions requiring this declaration are abated. 
WHEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED: 
(1)  That the applicable local emergency operations plan is hereby activated; 
(2)  That the following sections of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Union City be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, choose from the following: Section _____-5, Overcharging; Section _____-6, Registration of Building and Repair Services; Section _____-7, Closed or Restricted Areas and Curfews]; and 
(3)  That the following measures also be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, select items from Section _____-2(a)(4)c, d or such other measures as appropriate.] 
ENTERED at [TIME] on [DATE]. 
[Signed] 
Mayor, City of ___________." 
(c)  Contracts with local governments. In addition to the normal agreements embodied in the applicable local emergency operations plan for mutual emergency assistance, the city may contract with any municipality or county for the administration of a local emergency response program. 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 2-262. - Enforcement and remedies. 
(a)  Law enforcement. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-4, the city police department shall be authorized to enforce the orders, rules and regulations contained in this chapter and/or implemented by the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) or local governing authority during a declared emergency. 
(b)  Penalties. Failure to comply with any of the requirements or provisions of the regulations contained in this chapter, or with any code section, order, rule or regulation made effective by the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) or local governing authority upon or after the declaration of an emergency shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this chapter. Any person who violates any provision in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), imprisonment for a term not exceeding one hundred eighty (180) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, for each violation. Each person assisting in the commission of a violation, shall be guilty of separate offenses. Each day during which a violation or failure to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  Injunctive relief. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-5, in addition to the remedies prescribed in this section, the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.) is authorized to obtain an injunction to restrain violation of laws, code sections, orders, rules and regulations which are contained in the Georgia Emergency Management Act and/or this Code, and/or which are implemented by the local governing authority during a declared emergency. 
(d)  Enforcement. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, this article may be enforced by the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 2-263. - Authority to waive procedures and fee structures. 
(a)  City business. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the affairs and business of the city may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual location, within or outside of the city, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the city, all actions taken by the city governing authority shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the city. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two (2) members of the governing body without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. 
(b)  Public works contracts. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four (4) weeks; provided, however, that the emergency must be of such nature that immediate action is required and that the action is necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. Any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22(e). Any E-Verify affidavit or other state required affidavit shall be obtained from any contractor if otherwise required by law. 
(c)  Purchasing. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the purchasing ordinances, regulations or policies may be suspended. City officials shall continue to seek to obtain the best prices during the state of local emergency. 
(d)  Code enforcement. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or the mayor, the city governing authority may temporarily suspend the enforcement of the ordinances of the city, or any portion thereof, where the emergency is of such nature that immediate action outside the code is required, such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare, and such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. 
(e)  Fees. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or the mayor, the city may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" include fees or rates charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and clean up of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" does not include fees collected by the city on behalf of the state or federal government or fees charged by the city pursuant to a state or federal statute or regulation. 
(f)  Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city or its designees may issue temporary mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district, even though not otherwise permitted by development code, while the primary dwelling is being repaired. The temporary permit shall not exceed six (6) months in duration. Upon expiration of the temporary permit and/or extension, the temporary dwelling must be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 2-264. - Registration of building and repair services. 
(a)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-56, before building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to any real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures within an area in the city designated in a declared emergency or disaster, any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity must register with the city clerk and secure a building permit that is posted at the work site. Each day any such entity does business in the city without complying with this article constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  The cost of registration fees in a declared emergency or disaster is fixed at fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum. Registration is nontransferable. The cost of the emergency building permit shall be equal to the cost for a building permit under existing regulations. The permit shall only be authorized for repairs. 
(c)  When registering, any person, partnership, corporation or other entity making application must, under oath, complete an application, providing the following information: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Permanent address and phone number of applicant; 
(3)  Applicant's Social Security number or Federal Employer Identification number; 
(4)  If applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; 
(5)  Tag registration information for each vehicle to be used in the business; 
(6)  List of cities and/or counties where the applicant has conducted business within the past twelve (12) months; 
(7)  Georgia sales tax number or authorization; 
(8)  Georgia business license number, if required; 
(9)  Copy of license from Secretary of State, if required; 
(10)  A signed and sworn affidavit verifying the applicant's legal presence in the United States as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1; and 
(11)  At least one (1) secure and verifiable document as defined in O.C.G.A. § 50-36-2. 
(d)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration of emergency or otherwise extended by the city governing authority, the provisions of this Code section shall remain in effect during the state of emergency and for a subsequent recover period of three (3) months. 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Sec. 2-265. - Closed or restricted areas and curfews during emergency. 
(a)  To preserve, protect or sustain the life, health, welfare or safety of persons, or their property, within a designated area under a declaration of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person to travel, loiter, wander or stroll in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any other place during a declared emergency between hours specified by the mayor until the curfew is lifted. 
(b)  To promote order, protect lives, minimize the potential for looting and other crimes, and facilitate recovery operations during an emergency, the mayor shall have discretion to impose reentry restrictions on certain areas. The mayor shall exercise such discretion in accordance with the applicable local emergency operations plan, which shall be followed during emergencies. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons acting in the following capacities: 
(1)  Authorized and essential law enforcement personnel; 
(2)  Authorized and essential health care providers; 
(3)  Authorized and essential personnel of the city; 
(4)  Authorized National Guard or federal military personnel; 
(5)  Authorized and essential firefighters; 
(6)  Authorized and essential emergency response personnel; 
(7)  Authorized and essential personnel or volunteers working with or through an emergency management agency (EMA); 
(8)  Authorized and essential utility repair crews; 
(9)  Citizens seeking to restore order to their homes or businesses while on their own property or place of business; 
(10)  Other authorized and essential persons as designated on a list compiled by the fire chief (see subsection 2-261(a)(4)a.1.). 
(d)  Enforceability. This section shall be enforced by officers of the law enforcement personnel approved to provide aid and assistance during the emergency. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit a law enforcement officer from bringing other charges under state law. 
(e)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2012-27, § 1, 12-18-12) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate the manufacture, sale or transportation of intoxicating liquors and alcoholic, malt and vinous beverages, § 1-103(17). 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, OCGA Title 3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Public drinking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any malt, vinous or spirituous beverage or any other form of alcoholic beverage, mixed or plain, in or on any of the following places within the city: 
(1)  Any street, alley, municipal building or facility, school or auditorium; 
(2)  Any public place where games or contests are played, e.g., a baseball park, football field, tennis court and other places where people assemble to engage in or view games or athletic events; and 
(3)  Any public parking lot and any parking area incidental to a commercial or industrial enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 80-9, 11-4-80) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 12. 
Secs. 3-2-3-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPIRITUOUS LIQUOR DEALERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-16. - Purpose of article. 
    This article has been enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the following purposes, among others: to promote the health and general welfare of the community, to establish reasonable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sales of spirituous liquors, to protect and preserve schools and churches, to give effect to existing land use and to preserve certain residential areas, with reasonable considerations, among others, to the character of the areas and their peculiar suitability for particular uses, the congestion in the roads and streets, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining stability of neighborhood and property values, and to protect against the evils of concentration of the retail outlets for spirituous liquors in one (1) family or to prevent undesirable persons from controlling the retail liquor industry. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-17. - Definitions. 
    Interest in license. As used in this article, an "interest in a license" shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license, a co-owner of the license, a partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license, a stockholder in any corporation organized for the pecuniary gain which owns all or any part of a license, an owner, lessor, sublessor or stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain owning or leasing any real estate which is occupied by a retail spirituous liquor store or shares in any of the income or corpus of any trust or estate having any interest in a retail spirituous liquor store; provided, however, that a stockholder shall not be deemed to have an interest in a retail spirituous liquor store where he owns stock in a motel or hotel having two hundred (200) or more rooms with a retail spirituous liquor store located on the premises of such motel or hotel and owned by such motel or hotel. Notwithstanding any of the other provisions of this section, no one (1) person shall have more than one (1) interest in any one (1) license in the city. 
    Spirituous liquors. "Spirituous liquors" shall be deemed to include, but not be limited to, whiskey, rum, gin, brandy, vodka, tequila and all alcoholic beverages of similar nature and a similar alcoholic content. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. 
Sec. 3-18. - Penalties for violation of article or application irregularities. 
(a)  Any person who acquires a license or a renewal of same in violation of this article by any misrepresentation or fraudulent statement shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished in accordance with section 1-17. 
(b)  Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material omission left out of, an original, renewal or transfer application for a retail liquor license shall be cause for the denial thereof and if any license has been granted under these circumstances, there shall be cause for the revocation of same. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-19. - Retail licensee prohibited from having first direct financial interest in wholesale liquor business. 
    No person shall hold a retail license who also has any direct financial interest in any wholesale liquor business. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-20. - Personal restrictions on interest in retail license. 
(a)  After the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, no person or member of his family shall own, hold or control any interest whatsoever in more than one (1) license to engage in the business of selling spirituous liquors at retail in the city. 
(b)  No more than one (1) license to engage in the sale of spirituous liquors at retail in the city shall be issued to any person which shall include all members of such person's family. 
(c)  "Family" shall be deemed to include any person related to the holder of such license within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity as computed according to the civil law. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any elected or appointed official or employee of the city, or his spouse or minor children, to have any whole, partial or beneficial interest in any license to operate retail spirituous liquor stores in the city.
