(b)  The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell, serve, or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on such premises within the city limits of Union City: 
(1)  The employment or use of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume, or clothing, as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or of any portion of the male or female pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva and genitals. 
(2)  Live entertainment where any person appears in the manner described in paragraph (1) of this section or where such persons (or person) perform(s) acts of, or acts which simulate any of the following: 
a.  Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation, or any sexual act which is prohibited by law; 
b.  The caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals; 
c.  The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. 
(3)  The holding, promotion, sponsoring or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in paragraphs (1) and (2) above; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section (b) shall apply to the premises of any mainstream performance house, museum or theater which derives less than twenty (20) percent of its gross annual income from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this enactment are severable and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section hereof shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this enactment, since the same would have been enacted by the mayor and council without the incorporation herein of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(d)  All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(e)  This section shall be come effective on February 15, 1994. 
(Ord. No. 79-14, § 207, 12-4-79; Ord. No. 94-5, § 2, 2-15-94) 
Secs. 3-382-3-399. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - EXCISE TAX[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Taxation and finance, Ch. 14. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-400. - Imposed on sales of malt beverages. 
    In addition to all other taxes or license fees imposed upon dealers engaged in the city in the business of selling malt beverages as defined in and under the laws of the state, and the ordinances of the city, there is imposed and levied upon all such dealers within the city an excise tax on malt beverages to be based, computed and collected at the rate of .4166 cents per ounce. Fractional parts of cases, barrels, kegs, drums or other containers shall be computed proportionately. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-401. - Tax on wholesale sales of vinous liquors and spirituous liquors; wholesaler's license fee. 
    In addition to all other taxes or license fees, there is hereby imposed and levied a special or excise tax upon the wholesale sales of vinous liquors and spirituous liquors with a wholesaler's license fee as follows: 
(1)  Spirituous liquors, per liter ..... $0.22 
(2)  Vinous liquors, per liter ..... 0.22 
(3)  Wholesaler's license fee, per year ..... 100.00 
(Code 1976, § 15-201; Ord. No. 81-4, 4-21-81; Ord. No. 99-22, § 1, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-402. - Payment of taxes by wholesale dealers; monthly reports. 
    Wholesale dealers and distributors of such product shall report to the city clerk on or before the tenth day of the month, next succeeding the calendar month, of the total of such products sold or distributed within the city limits during the previous month and shall accompany such report with a payment of the tax due at the rate established in section 3-401 based upon the quantities of such products so sold the previous month. Each monthly report shall be accompanied by a sworn statement that such report is a true and correct report of all sales and shipments made within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-403. - Wholesale dealers and distributors; records and reports. 
    The license tax imposed by this division shall be computable and payable monthly as previously set forth. Each wholesale dealer or distributor selling, shipping, or delivering malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors to any retail dealer in the city, whether delivered to the retail dealer's place of business in the city or elsewhere for resale in the city, shall as a condition to the privilege of carrying on the business in the city make a true and correct record of all sales, shipments or deliveries of such products to each retail dealer in the city and immediately transmit a true and correct copy of such record to the city clerk at city hall. The record shall show the name of each retail dealer to whom a sale, shipment or delivery is made, the quantity and such other information as may be called for by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-404. - Failure to make reports. 
(a)  If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the report provided for in this division and to collect and transmit such taxes to the city, the city shall notify such party in writing, and if the report is not made within five (5) days from the date of the notice, the city may withdraw from the wholesale dealer or distributor the privilege of doing business in the city by revoking his license. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article for any wholesale dealer or distributor to deliver any malt beverages, vinous liquors or spirituous liquors to any retail dealer in the city without making a report to the city as provided in this division. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Sec. 3-405. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating or assisting in the violation of any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof in the recorders court, be subject to punishment as provided for in section 1-17. Such person so convicted shall also be subject to having his license revoked, if he shall be a licensed dealer in malt beverages, wines or spirituous liquors, either at wholesale or retail. 
(Code 1976, § 15-201) 
Secs. 3-406-3-415. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SALES OF SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS BY THE DRINK[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 99-22, adopted Nov. 16, 1999, enacted a new title to Div. 2. Sections 3-10 deleted §§ 3-416-3-423 in their entirety and enacted similar provisions to read as herein set out. Former §§ 3-416-3-423 derived from Ord. No. 79-10, §§ 7.1-7.8, adopted Sept. 4, 1979. 

Sec. 3-416. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Drink. Any spirituous liquors served for consumption on the premises which may or may not be diluted by any other liquid. 
    Licensee. Any person who holds a permit from the city to sell spirituous liquors by the drink. 
    Monthly. The calendar month of the year. 
    Purchase price. The consideration received for the sale of spirituous liquor by the drink valued in money, whether received in cash or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the licensee to the purchaser, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
    Purchaser. Any person who orders and gives present or future consideration for any spirituous liquor by the drink. 
    Tax. The tax imposed by this division. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 3, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-417. - Tax Levied. 
    There is hereby imposed and levied upon every sale of spirituous liquor purchased by the drink in the city a tax in the amount of three (3) percent of the purchase price of the drink. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 4, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-418. - Billing by licensee; liability. 
    Every licensee licensed for the sale of spirituous liquor by the drink operating a place of business in the city shall, at the time of collecting for food and drinks served, give to the purchaser a receipt on which the price of spirituous liquor served shall be itemized separately. Where the charges for food and drink are satisfied by credit or deferred payment, the payment of the tax to the licensee may be deferred in a like manner; however, the licensee shall be liable therefor at the time and to the extent that such credits are incurred. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 5, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-419. - Tax collection; information to city. 
    Every licensee or his agent is hereby authorized and directed to collect the tax herein imposed from purchaser's spirituous liquor by the drink sold within his licensed premises. Such licensee or his agent shall furnish such information as may be requested by the city to facilitate the collection of this tax. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 6, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-420. - Payment of tax by licensee; collection fee; penalty and interest. 
(a)  Due date of taxes. All taxes collected by any licensee or agent under the provisions of this division shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the twentieth day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly, as set forth in this division. 
(b)  Return; time of filing; persons required to file; execution. On or before the twentieth day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the city clerk in such form as the city may prescribe by every licensee or agent liable for the payment of tax required by this division. 
(c)  Contents of return. All returns shall show the gross receipts from the sale of spirituous liquors by the drink, amount of tax collected or authorized due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the city. 
(d)  Delivery of return and remittance. The person required to file the return shall deliver the return, together with the remittance of the net amount of tax due to the city clerk at the city hall. 
(e)  Collection fees allowed licensees. Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be three (3) percent for the first three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) of tax and one-half (1/2) percent of the amount of tax in excess of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). 
(f)  Penalty and interest for untimely payment. A penalty of fifteen (15) percent shall be imposed for failure to pay the full amount of tax when due and payable to the city. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 7, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-421. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person, he/she may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his/her possession or that may come into his/her possession. One (1) or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Interest and penalty on deficiency. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day after the close of the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. A penalty of fifteen (15) percent shall be imposed upon the amount of any determination. 
(c)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the city clerk may offset overpayment; for a period or periods, against underpayments, for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the interest on underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in section 3-422(c). 
(d)  Notice of city clerk's determination; service thereof. The city clerk, or his/her designated representative, shall give to the licensee written notice of his/her determination. The notice may be served personally or by certified mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the licensee at his address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. In the case of service by mail of any notice required by this section, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States Post Office. 
(e)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three (3) years after the twentieth day of the calendar month following the monthly period to which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three (3) years after the return is filed whichever period should last expire. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 8, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-422. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee from the sale of spirituous liquors by the drink, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total sales in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city clerk. Upon the basis of this estimate, the city clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to fifteen (15) percent thereof. One (1) or more determinations may be made for one (1) or more periods. 
(b)  Manner of computation; offset; interest. In making a determination, the city clerk may offset overpayments for a period or penalties, and against the interest on the underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day of the month following a monthly period, for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(d)  Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his/her determination, the city clerk shall give to the person written notice to be served personally or by certified mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. 
(Ord. No. 99-22, § 9, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-423. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-424. - Collection of delinquent tax; duty of assignees; liability; offsetting erroneous collections. 
(a)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the city may bring in action in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees, and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any licensee liable for any amount under this division sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city clerk showing that the tax has been paid, or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold, certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the necessary amount from the purchase price as heretofore required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. Within thirty (30) days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the city clerk shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the city of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall begin at the time the licensee sells out his business or at the time that the determination against the licensee becomes final, whichever event occurs the later. 
(d)  Tax credit, penalty or interest paid more than once or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under this division, it may be offset as provided in section 3-421(c). If the licensee determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the city clerk, he will have three (3) years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the city, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the licensee by whom it was paid, or his administrators or executors. 
(Ord. No. 79-10, § 7.9, 9-4-79; Ord. No. 99-22, §§ 11, 12, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-425. - Administration; enforcement; rules; records; confidentiality. 
(a)  Authority of the city clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this division. 
(b)  Rules and regulations. The city clerk shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this division or other laws of the city and the state, or the constitution of this state or the United States for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this division and the collection of the taxes hereunder. 
(c)  Records required from licensee; form. Every licensee for the sale of spirituous liquor by the drink in the city shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the city clerk may require. 
(d)  Examination of records; audits. The city clerk or any person authorized in writing by the city may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, inventory, equipment and other facilities of any licensee liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the licensee, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(e)  Authority to require reports; contents. In the administration of the provisions of this division, the city clerk may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's possession or custody information relating to sales of alcoholic beverages which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city clerk and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the date or dates of sales, and such other information as the city clerk may require. 
(f)  Disclosure of business of operators, etc.; limitation on rule. The city clerk or any person having an administrative duty under this division, shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures or any particulars thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or to permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this section, except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax hereby levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, upon satisfactory proof of interest, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax required to be collected, interest and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 79-10, § 7.10, 9-4-79; Ord. No. 99-22, §§ 13, 14, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 3-426. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor offense and upon conviction thereof in the city court shall be assessed a fine for each such offense in accordance with section 1-17. 
(b)  Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of this division is committed, continued, or permitted by such person, and shall be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 79-10, § 7.11, 9-4-79) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to provide animal control, § 1-102(c)(3); authority to regulate, license or prohibit the keeping and running at large of animals and fowl, § 1-103(35). 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for animal control, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, Sec. II, Para. III(a)(3); animals generally, OCGA Title 4. 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal control officer. The words "animal control officer" shall refer to an individual employed by the health department or its designee to perform and execute the provisions of this chapter. 
    Animal control shelter. The words "animal control shelter" shall refer to the facilities operated by the health department or its designee for the confining of dogs, cats, other animals or fowl impounded under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Cat. The word "cat" shall mean any domesticated feline, of either sex, whether vaccinated against rabies or not. 
    Commercial guard/security dog. The words "commercial guard/security dog" shall mean any dog that is purchased, leased, or rented and that is trained to guard, protect, patrol, or defend any commercial property, public or private, upon and within which it is located. 
    Current vaccination/license tag. The words "current vaccination/license tag" shall refer to a vaccination/license tag bearing a number which shows the license is valid for a one-or three-year period. The licensing period runs concurrently with the vaccination period. 
    Custodian. The word "custodian" shall mean any person who has been entrusted with the responsibility and care of a dog, cat, other animal or fowl by its owner. 
    Dog. The word "dog" shall mean any domesticated canine, of either sex, whether vaccinated against rabies or not. 
    Domestic animal/fowl. The words "domestic animal/fowl" shall mean any animal/fowl domesticated by humans so as to live and breed in a tame condition for the advantage of humans. Pen-raised skunks are categorized as those skunks acceptable by the state and may be kept in the state as pets. 
    Exotic animal/fowl. The words "exotic animal/fowl" shall mean any animal/fowl of any kind which is not indigenous to the state and not included in the definition of a domestic animal/fowl, and shall include any hybrid animal/fowl which is part wild animal/fowl. 
    Harborer. The word "harborer" shall mean any person who has provided sustenance and/or shelter to a dog, cat, or other animal or fowl for a period of more than seven (7) days. 
    Health department. The words "health department" shall mean the county commissioner of health, or his authorized representatives, which shall include officers or employees of the Atlanta Humane Society so long as such corporation is under contract with the county and other cities of the county. 
    Livestock. The word "livestock" shall include horses, mules, cows, sheep, goats, hogs and all other animals used or suitable for either food or labor. 
    Nuisance. The word "nuisance" shall mean whatever is dangerous or detrimental to human life or health and whatever renders or tends to render the soil, air, water or food impure or unwholesome or unreasonably offends or impairs the senses of smell, sight and hearing. 
    Vaccinate. The word "vaccinate" shall mean the injection, by a veterinarian, of a specified dose of anti-rabies vaccine intramuscular or subcutaneous of an animal, such vaccine having the U.S. government license number of approval stamped on the label of the vaccine container and having been approved by the state department of human resources. Vaccine used for vaccination of dogs, cats or other animals against rabies shall be refrigerated and kept under proper conditions and shall show no signs of spoilage or otherwise be unfit for producing immunity against rabies. 
    Vaccination certificate. The words "vaccination certificate" shall refer to a certificate provided by the state department of human resources and issued at the time of vaccination of the dog, cat or other animal and bearing thereon the signature of the vaccinator, the name, color, breed, age and sex of the dog, cat or other animal, the name and address of the owner, the date of expiration of the vaccination, and spay or neuter status if known by the administering veterinarian. 
    Vaccination/license tag. The words "vaccination/license tag" shall refer to a metal tag bearing a number which is issued to the animal owner after showing proof of vaccination for the animal and paying, when required, the license fee. This tag is issued on behalf of the county by the health department or its designee and is provided by the state department of human resources. 
    Veterinarian. The word "veterinarian" shall mean any person who holds a license to practice the profession of veterinary medicine in the state. The veterinary license number shall be the same as that recorded by the state board of veterinary examiners. 
    Vicious animal/fowl. The words "vicious animal/fowl" shall mean any animal/fowl which attacks, bites or injures humans, other animals or fowl without provocation; or which, because of temperament, conditioning or training, has a known propensity to attack, bite or injure other living creatures without provocation; or an animal/fowl which has on one (1) or more occasions caused injury to other living creatures without provocation; or any animal which constitutes a physical threat to human beings or domesticated animals by one (1) or more attacks without provocation of such severity to cause physical injury. An animal/fowl is not considered vicious if it attacks, bites or menaces: 
(1)  Anyone attacking the owner; 
(2)  Unlawful trespassers on the property of the owner; 
(3)  Any person or animal that has tormented or abused it; 
(4)  If it is defending its young or another animal. 
    Wildlife/fowl. The words "wildlife/fowl" shall mean any animal/fowl of any kind which is indigenous to the state but not included in the definition of a domestic animal/fowl, and shall include any hybrid animal/fowl which is part wild animal/fowl. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § A, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-2. - Vaccination required. 
(a)  The owner, custodian or harborer of each dog or cat over four (4) months of age kept, maintained or harbored in any area of the county including any dog or cat within the corporate city limits of any municipality in the county, is required to maintain a current rabies vaccination on such dog or cat. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all persons owning or having custody of any dog or cat over four (4) months of age brought into the county from outside the county to have such dog or cat vaccinated within fourteen (14) days from date of entry, provided that when the owner or person having custody of the dog or cat produces evidence satisfactory to the health department through its designee that such dog or cat has a current vaccination as prescribed by this chapter, such dog or cat will not be required to be vaccinated again until the expiration date of the current vaccination. 
(c)  Only a licensed veterinarian shall be entitled in connection with his practice, on request of any owner of a dog, cat or other animal, to vaccinate such dog, cat or other animal against rabies, with a vaccine as set forth in section 4-1, provided that at the time of vaccination he furnishes two (2) copies of the vaccination certificate to the owner, forwards one (1) copy to the Fulton-Atlanta S.P.C.A. and maintains one (1) copy for his files. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § B, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-3. - Dog license required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each owner, custodian or harborer of any dog over four (4) months of age kept, maintained or harbored within the unincorporated area of the county or within any municipality in the county who has or may enter into an agreement with the county for animal control services, to obtain a dog license for such dog. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all persons owning or having custody of any dog over four (4) months of age brought into the areas of the county designated in subsection (a) of this section to obtain a dog license for such dog within fourteen (14) days from the date of entry. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § C, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-4. - Vaccination/license tag required. 
(a)  In order to maintain a centrally located record of all vaccinated dogs, cats or other animals kept, maintained or harbored in any area of the county including those within the corporate city limits of any municipality in the county, the owner, custodian or harborer of such dog, cat or other animal is required to apply to the Fulton-Atlanta S.P.C.A. for a vaccination/license tag. 
(b)  A vaccination/license tag shall be issued upon presentation of a certificate showing that the dog, cat or other animal for which the tag is issued has been vaccinated as prescribed by this chapter, provided that the owner, custodian, or harborer of any dog in the areas of the county designated in section 4-3(a) also makes payment of a license fee to be set by the county commissioners. The vaccination/license tag will be available to the public throughout the year and is issued on behalf of the county by the health department or its designee. The tax shall be valid for the same period as the time specified by the vaccination. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the owner, custodian or harborer of any dog in the areas designated in section 4-3(a) to affix such vaccination/license tag to a collar worn by the dog at all times; except that the wearing of a vaccination/license tag is not required for show dogs where the wearing of such tag could damage the coat, and except dogs when boarded in kennels or veterinary clinics, or when in an area zoned for agricultural purposes where the owner or custodian of the dog in question is using the dog for hunting purposes, and has on his person a valid hunting license. In the latter case, the owner, custodian or harborer shall have the tag or vaccination certificate in his possession where it may be shown on demand by any duly constituted authority. 
(d)  Should the vaccination/license tag become lost, misplaced, or stolen, it shall be the duty of the owner, custodian or harborer of the dog to obtain a replacement tag at a cost as set by the county commissioners. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attach a vaccination/license tag to the collar of any animal for which it was not issued, or to remove a vaccination/license tag from any animal without the consent of the owner or custodian. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § D, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-5. - Special permits for kennels. 
(a)  Each premises where there are four (4) or more dogs over the age of four (4) months, kept, maintained or harbored for a period of fourteen (14) days or longer, shall be deemed to constitute a kennel. The owner or person in possession of the premises where the kennel is located shall be required to apply for a special permit. 
(b)  A special permit will be issued upon payment of an annual fee set by the county commissioners and proof that the premises and dogs covered by the special permit meet the requirements set out in this chapter. 
(c)  The special permit will be valid for one (1) year from date of issue, provided it is not revoked during the year for violation of this chapter. Application to renew a special permit must be made at least fourteen (14) days prior to the expiration of the existing permit. 
(d)  Individual license tags will be issued for each dog located in such a kennel and a separate tag fee over and above the annual special permit fee will not be required. 
(e)  All commercial kennels which are subject to a business license fee shall be exempt from the annual special permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § E, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-6. - Rabies cases to be reported. 
    It shall be the duty of any person knowing of a rabid animal or of any animal showing symptoms of rabies to immediately report such animal to the health department or its designee and give as much pertinent information as possible. Any bite by an animal shall be reported to the health department or its designee. The animal control office, in order to maintain an effective epidemiological surveillance and control program, shall maintain a record of its rabies related activities, including investigation and confirmation of rabies in animals in the manner and frequency stipulated by the health department. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § F, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-7. - Quarantine. 
(a)  If a dog or cat has bitten a human, such animal shall be immediately confined at the animal control shelter, veterinary hospital or other such premises deemed acceptable by the health department or its designee for a period of ten (10) days from the date of the bite to be observed for symptoms of rabies. 
(b)  If an animal other than a dog or cat has bitten a human, another dog, cat or other animal, the recommendations contained in the rabies control manual compiled by the state department of human resources shall be followed. 
(c)  All expenses incurred for boarding an animal for the quarantine period as well as other applicable fees shall be paid by the owner or custodian of the biting animal. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, custodian or harborer to fail to surrender a dog, cat or other animal which has bitten a human, for quarantine or laboratory examination, upon the sworn statement of the person bitten. The provisions of this section shall apply regardless of whether or not such animal has a current rabies vaccination and tag. 
(e)  Where rabies has been found to exist in any warm-blooded animal, or where its existence is suspected, the health department or its designee may designate an area within which quarantine of all owned warm-blooded animals shall be maintained. Such animals shall be immediately confined to the premises designated and in a manner approved by the health department or its designee whether or not such animals have been vaccinated against rabies. 
(f)  No animal shall be brought into or removed from a quarantined area or premises without written approval of the health department or its designee. 
(g)  Quarantine ordered by the health department or its designee shall be maintained for such period as deemed necessary to protect the public health. 
(h)  Quarantined areas or premises where rabid animals or animals suspected of having rabies remain at large, may be posted by the health department with signs which read as follows: "Rabies Suspected" or "Rabies-Keep Away From Animals." Such signs shall be conspicuously displayed in a place designated by the health department and shall not be removed except by the health department. Such signs shall not be defaced. 
(i)  The owner, custodian, or harborer of each animal subject to a quarantine invoked by the health department under the terms of this chapter shall be notified of the quarantine, the particular animals subject thereto, and shall be given such other information as the health department deems necessary. 
(j)  Every animal showing clinical signs of rabies as determined by the health department shall be immediately destroyed, and the heads of all animals suspected of having had rabies at the time of death shall be submitted to the epidemiology office, department of human resources, for examination by the department of human resources laboratory. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § G, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-8. - Running at large prohibited. 
(a)  Generally. Within the unincorporated areas of the county or within any municipality in the county which has or may enter into an agreement with the county for animal control services, the running at large of dogs, domestic animals/fowl, livestock, wildlife/fowl or exotic animals/fowl except cats, is prohibited. Owners of wildlife/fowl or exotic animals/fowl must have the necessary state or federal permits on their person when transporting their animals. 
(b)  Dogs. It shall be unlawful for the owner, custodian or harborer of any dog to allow or permit such dog to leave the premises of the owner or other such person having custody of the dog unless such dog shall be securely under leash, such leash not being more than six (6) feet long, and under the control of a competent person. Dogs must be confined to the premises of the owner or other such person having custody of the dog and shall be restrained by means of a fence or wall or other enclosure, or restrained individually by leash or chain. Excluded are those dogs participating in or training for obedience trials, field trials, dog shows, tracking work or law enforcement. Also, this requirement shall not apply in any area zoned for agriculture where the owner or person having custody of the dog is at the time in question using the dog for hunting purposes, and has on his person a valid hunting license and proof of vaccination. 
(c)  Domestic animal/fowl, livestock, owned wildlife/fowl, exotic animal/fowl. It shall be unlawful for the owner, custodian or harborer of any domestic animal/fowl, livestock, wildlife/fowl or exotic animal/fowl, except cats, to allow or permit such to leave the premises of the owner or other such person having custody of such unless securely under leash, in a carrying case or restrained by some other means and under the control of a competent person. Domestic animal/fowl, livestock, wildlife/fowl or exotic animal/fowl, except cats, shall be securely confined to the premises of the owner or other such person having custody of such by means set forth under the provisions of this section or approved by the health department or its designee or as required by state or federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § H, 8-14-87) 
State Law reference- Livestock running at large, OCGA §§ 4-3-1-4-3-12. 
Sec. 4-9. - Cruelty to animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to overload, poison, cruelly treat, maim, tease, bruise, deprive of necessary sustenance or medical attention, ill use, deprive of shade and shelter or in any manner whatsoever torture, kill or abuse any animal/fowl. 
(b)  No person shall abandon any animal/fowl, on any property, public or private, or keep an animal under unsanitary conditions. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to transport any dog in an open bed truck except when safely confined in a portable/transport kennel or safely restrained by a harness or tether. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § I, 8-14-87) 
State Law reference- Animal protection, OCGA § 4-11-1 et seq. 
Sec. 4-10. - Precautions to be taken by owners of vicious animals fowl. 
(a)  No person, owning or having custody or control of any dog or other animal/fowl known by such person to be vicious shall permit it to run at large, or permit it to run loose on or within the premises of such person in such a manner as to endanger the life or limb of any person lawfully entering such premises. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every owner of any vicious animal/fowl, or anyone having any such animal in his possession or custody, to ensure that the vicious animal/fowl is kept under restraint and that reasonable care and precautions are taken to prevent the vicious animal/fowl from leaving, while unattended, the real property limits of its owner, custodian or harborer, and it is securely and humanely enclosed within a house, building, fence, pen, or other enclosure out of which it cannot climb, dig, jump, or otherwise escape on its own volition, and such enclosure must be securely locked at any time the animal is left unattended. 
(c)  For owners of vicious animals/fowl who maintain their animals/fowl out-of-doors, a portion of their property should be fenced with a perimeter or area fence. Within this perimeter fence, the vicious animal/fowl must be humanely confined inside a pen or kennel of adequate size. The pen or kennel may not share common fencing with the area or perimeter fence. The kennel or pen must have secure sides and secure top attached to all sides. The sides must be securely set into the ground or onto a concrete pad or securely attached to a wire bottom. The gate to the kennel must be locked. 
(d)  A vicious animal shall not be upon any street or public place except when securely restrained by a leash not more than six (6) feet in length and humanely muzzled and in the charge of a competent person. 
(e)  Whenever outside of its enclosure as provided for in subsections (b) and (c), but on the owner's property, a vicious animal must be attended by the owner and restrained by a secure collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape. 
(f)  No vicious animal/fowl shall be chained, tethered, or otherwise tied to any inanimate object such as a tree, post, or building, outside of its own enclosure. 
(g)  A warning sign, i.e., "Beware Of Dog" shall be conspicuously posted denoting a vicious animal/fowl is on the premises. 
(h)  Failure to keep any vicious animal/fowl confined or under restraint as provided for in this section shall be unlawful and shall be punishable as provided in section 4-20. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § J, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-11. - Commercial guard/security dogs. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all persons who keep, use or maintain any guard/security dog to have signs conspicuously posted on the premises where the guard/security dog is located to warn of the presence of the dog. This warning shall consist of a warning sign placed at each entrance to and exit from the premises and in a position to be legible from the sidewalk or ground level adjacent to the sign (eye level). If the premises is not enclosed by a wall or fence, a sign shall be placed at every entrance to and exit from each structure on the premises in which a guard/security dog is located. Each sign shall measure at least ten (10) inches by fourteen (14) inches and shall contain block lettering stating "Warning, Guard Dog On Duty." In addition, for dogs rented or leased, the sign shall set forth the name, address and phone number of the responsible person or persons, to be notified during any hour of the day or night. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any person who keeps, uses, or maintains a guard/security dog to ensure the dog is vaccinated against rabies and licensed as required by section 4-4(b). The dog also must have the current vaccination tag affixed to a collar worn by the dog at all times as required by section 4-4(c). 
(c)  It shall be the duty of any person that sells, leases, and/or rents any guard/security dog to be used within the county to notify the county animal control S.P.C.A. of the location and number of guard/security dogs in use, kept, or maintained at a particular location. The animal control office shall maintain a record of the location, number of guard/security dogs, and current rabies vaccination and licensure of all guard/security dogs utilized within the county. 
(d)  The person that sells, leases, and/or rents a guard/security dog to be used in the county shall furnish the following information to the county animal control office: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the location where a guard/security dog is located; 
(2)  Name, breed, sex, current license tag information of each guard/security dog at any location in the county. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to transport any guard/security dog in an open bed truck and the vehicle transporting guard/security dogs shall be identified as to the business owner. It shall be unlawful to transport any guard/security dog in the county except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Each dog shall be placed in separate holding bins; 
(2)  Each holding bin shall be enclosed and measure forty-eight (48) inches long by eighteen (18) inches wide by thirty (30) inches high; 
(3)  Each holding bin will be adequately ventilated. 
(f)  No guard/security dog shall be chained, tethered, or otherwise tied to any inanimate object such as a tree, post or building outside of its own enclosure. 
(g)  A guard/security dog shall be confined by the owner, custodian or harborer within a building or secure enclosure out of which it cannot climb, dig, jump or otherwise escape on its own volition. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § K, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-12. - Confinement of female dogs in heat required. 
    It shall be the duty of any owner, custodian or harborer of any female dog in heat within the areas designated in section 4-3(a), when she is left unattended, to securely confine such dog inside a building or other enclosure to prevent such dog from coming into contact with another dog except for planned breeding. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § L, 8-14-87) 
State Law reference- Permitting dogs in heat to run free prohibited, OCGA § 4-8-6. 
Sec. 4-13. - Impoundment of dogs, domestic animals/fowl, livestock, owned wildlife/fowl, exotic animals/fowl. 
(a)  Dogs, domestic animals/fowl, livestock, owned wildlife/fowl, and exotic animals/fowl within any of the following classes may be captured and impounded from the areas noted in section 4-3(a) with the exception of subparagraphs (1) through (5) of this subsection which shall also apply to any area of the county not under contract for animal control services: 
(1)  Dogs without a current rabies vaccination; 
(2)  Dogs without a current county license; 
(3)  Dogs not wearing a current vaccination/license tag. Includes dogs wearing a tag that was not issued for the dog; 
(4)  Dogs or other animals which have bitten a human or animal or which have been bitten by a dog or other animal suspected of having rabies or in what appears to be an unprovoked attack; 
(5)  Dogs or other animals suspected of having rabies; 
(6)  Unconfined dogs or other animals in quarantine areas; 
(7)  Dogs or other animals/fowl whose safety, health or life is in immediate danger; 
(8)  Dogs, domestic animals/fowl, livestock or exotic animals/fowl, except cats, whose ownership is unknown; 
(9)  Dogs, domestic animals/fowl, livestock, owned wildlife/fowl or exotic animals/fowl, except cats, roaming at large; 
(10)  Vicious dogs or other animals/fowl not properly confined or restrained as defined in section 4-10; 
(11)  Commercial guard/security dogs not properly confined or restrained as defined in section 4-11; 
(12)  Dogs in heat not properly confined as defined in section 4-12. 
(b)  No dog or other animal shall be exempt from the provisions of this section by virtue of a vaccination tag or certificate. 
(c)  Any animal control officer empowered to perform any duty under the provisions of this chapter is hereby authorized to go upon any premises to seize for impounding a dog or other animal/fowl which the officer is in immediate pursuit of with the exception of any occupied building into which the dog or other animal/fowl may enter. In the latter case, if the occupant or owner of the premises gives permission to the animal control officer to enter the premises, the officer may remove the dog or other animal/fowl. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to, in any manner, interfere with, hinder, resist, obstruct, or molest the animal control officer in the performance of his duties, or for any person to remove any animal/fowl from the animal control vehicle without the permission of the animal control officer. 
(e)  When the owner of the dog or other animal/fowl, impounded under the provisions of this chapter, can be readily identified and located, the health department or its designee shall notify the owner of the impoundment. A reasonable attempt to contact the owner shall be satisfied by a telephone call to the owner's residence when possible or a postcard sent to the owner's residence through the U.S. Postal Service. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § M, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-14. - Skunks and foxes. 
    All skunks, except domestic skunks, and all foxes, from whatever geographic region including Alaska and Canada, are forbidden to be purchased, sold, owned, possessed or harbored. Skunks and foxes in possession as of July 1, 1987 are grandfathered. Domestic skunks, other than black and white skunks, may be purchased and kept as pets after securing a permit from the Fulton-Atlanta Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The S.P.C.A. is responsible for ensuring that purchasers of domestic skunks are made knowledgeable of the proper care, handling and confinement. No pet store shall allow the purchase of domestic skunks without being first presented with the permit issued by the Fulton-Atlanta S.P.C.A. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § N, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-15. - Wildlife/fowl or exotic animal/fowl permits required. 
    Each owner, custodian or harborer of any wildlife/fowl or exotic animal/fowl must obtain all necessary state and federal permits for such animal or fowl. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § O, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-16. - Disposition of impounded animals. 
(a)  Every animal/fowl impounded under the provisions of this chapter which is found upon arrival at the animal control shelter to be diseased or injured, and whose ownership is unknown or is relinquished in writing, shall, at the discretion of the health department or its designee, be immediately destroyed if not accepted by an organization approved by the health department or its designee and provided such organization signs a receipt for the animal/fowl. If an owner cannot be contacted and the severity of the injury or disease of the animal dictates that euthanasia is a humane course of action, the animal will be destroyed and the owner, if known, notified as soon as possible. 
(b)  If, in the opinion of the health department or its designee, the release of an impounded animal/fowl will impair the safety of the public, such animal/fowl will be held pending a court ordered disposition. 
(c)  Any animal/fowl impounded under the provisions of this chapter shall be held a minimum of three (3) days from the day of impoundment or such longer period of time as deemed reasonable by the director of animal control. Animals under observation for rabies symptoms shall remain in the animal control shelter for such period of time as the health department or its designee may deem necessary to protect the public health. Livestock shall be held a minimum of fourteen (14) days. 
(d)  Impounded animals/fowl not claimed within three (3) days of the day of impoundment or at the end of the quarantine period shall be disposed of (euthanized) in a humane manner as approved by the health department or its designee. At the discretion of the health department or its designee, animals/fowl not claimed by the person having the right of possession may be offered for adoption or placement with any person or organization approved by the health department or its designee. No animal/fowl impounded under the provisions of this section shall be released to any person or organization for the purpose of live animal experimentation. 
(e)  Before being released, the owner of any impounded animal/fowl shall pay the following: 
(1)  A vaccination fee on any unvaccinated animal when a vaccination is required by this chapter; 
(2)  A license fee for any unlicensed dog in an area covered by this chapter; 
(3)  An impoundment fee; 
(4)  A daily boarding fee. 
(f)  The county commission shall, by resolution, establish reasonable vaccination, license, impoundment and boarding fees. In some instances the amount of impoundment and boarding fees will be on a cost incurred basis. 
(g)  Proceeds from license, impoundment and boarding fees shall be applied to the annual operating budget of the Fulton-Atlanta S.P.C.A. for the control of rabies, animal control, enforcement and operation of the animal facility. 
(h)  The health department or its designee shall exercise every reasonable care to prevent injury, illness, death, escape or pilfering of any animal/fowl with which it deals but shall not be responsible for any such occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § P, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-17. - Nuisances. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any domestic animal/fowl or livestock except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Any housing or enclosure used by any domestic animal/fowl or livestock shall be well-drained, free from accumulations of animal excrement and objectionable odors and otherwise clean and sanitary. Animal excrement shall be disposed of in a manner approved by the health officer. 
(2)  Domestic animal/fowl or livestock shall be kept at the following minimum distances from any occupied building except the dwelling unit of the owner, licensed veterinary hospitals, kennels, grooming parlors and public and commercial horse facilities: 
Animal/fowl Distance (feet) Horses, mules, asses, cows or sheep or goats ..... 150  Hogs ..... 900  Dogs (3 or more) ..... 25 Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters ..... 25 Chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pigeons or similar fowl ..... 25  
(3)  Except in areas zoned for agriculture, licensed veterinary hospitals, kennels, grooming parlors and public and commercial horse facilities, each domestic animal/fowl or livestock shall be provided with the following average minimum floor or ground area in the enclosure or housing in which it is kept: 
Animal/fowl Area per 
animal/fowl 
(sq. feet) Horses, mules, asses, cows, sheep or goats ..... 150 Hogs ..... 150 Dogs ..... 100 Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters ..... 4 Chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pigeons or similar fowl ..... 4  
(4)  Except in areas zoned for agriculture, licensed veterinary hospitals, kennels, grooming parlors and public and commercial horse facilities, the maximum number of domestic animals/fowl or livestock that may be kept on any single premises shall not exceed the following: 
Animal/fowl Maximum 
number Horses, mules, asses, cows .....  5 Sheep, goats ..... 10 Hogs ..... 10 Dogs, cats ..... 10 Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters ..... 75 Chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pigeons or similar fowl ..... 75  
(Ord. No. 87-34, § Q, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-18. - Animals/fowl as prizes forbidden. 
    It shall be unlawful to offer as a prize or give away any animal/fowl in any contest, raffle or lottery or as enticement for fund-raising or for entry into any place of business. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § R, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-19. - Enforcement. 
    The county board of health or its designee shall enforce the provisions of this chapter by means of impoundment and court citations. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § T, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-20. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment in jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days or both. Each and every violation of the provisions of this chapter constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  Any vicious animal/fowl, as defined in section 4-1 shall be deemed to be a nuisance and may be abated as a nuisance upon the conviction thereafter of its owner of a violation of section 4-10. 
(Ord. No. 87-34, § S, 8-14-87) 
Sec. 4-21. - Cruelty to elephants. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "bullhook" shall mean a device or instrument containing a spike, hook, or any combination thereof. A bullhook is also known as an ankus, ankusha, elephant goad, or elephant hook. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a bullhook on an elephant within the jurisdiction of the City of Union City. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use on an elephant any device or instrument that inflicts pain on, or causes, or is likely to cause injury to, an elephant, except as necessary to administer legitimate medical treatment or in response to an immediate threat to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 1, 7-19-11) 
Chapter 5 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to provide building, housing, plumbing and electrical codes, § 1-102(c)(13); authority to regulate the erection and construction of buildings, § 1-103(16); authority to provide for the destruction and removal of dangerous buildings, § 1-103(24); authority to provide for the abatement of building nuisances, § 1-103(30); authority to provide for minimum standards for building construction and repair, § 1-103(32). 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 7; health and sanitation, Ch. 8; planning, Ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 12; utilities, Ch. 15.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Building permit fee schedule. 
(a)  No building permit required by the city shall be transmitted to an applicant until the fees set forth in subsection (b) below have been paid. Nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any shall be required, has been paid. 
(b)  The fees for inspection of buildings, whether for construction, removal or demolition; electrical installation or work; plumbing installation or work; heating and air conditioning installation or work; grading; drainage; curb gutters; and commercial drives, as are required by this chapter, shall be the same as those presently in force and as hereafter amended by the board of commissioners of the county. A copy of this fee schedule shall be kept and maintained by the city clerk for public reference. 
(Ord. No. 79-4, 5-15-79) 
Secs. 5-2-5-15. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-16. - Adoption of state minimum standard codes. 
    It is the intent of the City of Union City to enforce the latest edition of the following state minimum standard codes, and all appendices thereto, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs: 
(1)  International Building Code; 
(2)  National Electrical Code; 
(3)  International Fuel Gas Code; 
(4)  International Mechanical Code; 
(5)  International Plumbing Code;

(Ord. No. 98-11, § 1, 7-21-98; Ord. No. 2007-11, § 1, 4-17-07)

    The following codes, the latest edition as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, are hereby adopted by reference as though they were copied herein fully for the purpose of enforcement within the City of Union City: 
(1)  International Existing Building Code; and 
(2)  International Property Maintenance Code, as amended in section 5-18 of this Code of Ordinances.

(Ord. No. 2011-15, § 2, 9-20-11)

DIVISION 3. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 5-56. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted, for the purpose of establishing standards and procedures affecting the design, erection, and construction of buildings and structures, the International Building Code, 2006 edition with the Georgia State Amendments, as promulgated by the International Code Council, of which not less than one (1) copy has been and is on file in the office of the city clerk, and save and except such portions as hereinafter stricken or modified, is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1976, § 17-102; Ord. No. 80-10, § 1, 10-21-80; Ord. No. 86-7, § 3, 1-21-86; Ord. No. 89-5, § 2, 3-21-89; Ord. No. 91-9, § 3, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 2007-11, § 4, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 5-57. - Definitions. 
    As used in the building code adopted in this division: 
(1)  The words "building official" shall mean the officer or employee of the city whose duty it is to check and inspect buildings and the erection thereof to see that all building requirements of the city are met and complied with. 
(2)  The term "corporation counsel" shall include city attorney. 
(3)  The word "municipality" shall mean the city. 
(Code 1976, § 17-102) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-58. - Appeals from grievances. 
    Any person aggrieved may take an appeal to the city council from any action taken or order given under the building code adopted by this division. 
(Code 1976, § 17-102) 
Sec. 5-59. - Reserved.

DIVISION 4. - PLUMBING CODE 

Sec. 5-71. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations relating to the installation, repair, erection, alteration, use and maintenance of plumbing and sewer systems that are used, erected, installed or maintained in the city, that certain plumbing code known as the International Plumbing Code, 2006 edition with the Georgia State Amendments, and as thereafter amended or revised, as promulgated by the International Code Council, of which not less than one (1) copy has been and is on file in the office of the city clerk, and save and except such portions as are hereinafter stricken or modified, is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1976, § 17-103; Ord. No. 89-5, § 3, 3-21-89; Ord. No. 91-9, § 17, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 2007-11, § 6, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 5-72. - Fee schedules. 
    Section 107.4. Schedule of permit fees. On all buildings, structures, or alterations, requiring a building permit, as set forth in section 105, a fee shall be paid at the time of filing application in accordance with the following schedule: 
a.  Permit fees. 
1.  No permit required by the building code of the City of Union City shall be transmitted to the applicant until the fees set forth herein shall have been paid. Nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any shall be required, shall have been paid. 
2.  For a permit for construction or alteration of a building or structure, the fee shall be as follows: 
Three dollars ($3.00) per thousand dollars of the cost of the work to be performed and same being fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) cost or less with no fee less than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
Two dollars ($2.00) per thousand dollars of the cost of the work to be performed when said work exceeds fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in cost. 
3.  No fee required by this subsection shall be less than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
4.  For a permit for the removal of a building or structure from one lot to another, the fee shall be the same as would be required under subparagraph (2) above for new construction. Where the use of a street or streets of the city are required in the removal of a building or structure, the additional fee as required by a separate ordinance of the city shall be paid prior to the issuance of the permit for removal. 
5.  For a permit for the demolition of a building or structure the fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 91-9, § 18, 10-15-91) 
Secs. 5-73-5-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ELECTRICAL CODE 

Sec. 5-86. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted as the electrical code for the City of Union City, the National Electric Code, 2005 edition with the Georgia State Amendments, and as thereafter amended or revised, as promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association of which code not less than one (1) copy is on file in the office of the city clerk and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1976, § 17-104; Ord. No. 89-5, § 4, 3-21-89; Ord. No. 91-9, § 19, 10-15-91; Ord. No. 2007-11, § 7, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 5-87. - Permit required for work. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make, or cause to be made, any electrical installations or work to be done without first obtaining a permit to do such work or installation from the city clerk. An application for a permit shall be made to the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1976, § 17-104) 
Sec. 5-88. - Inspection, approval of all work required. 
    The electrical inspector shall inspect and approve all electrical installation in the city and such inspection must be made before any electrical work is covered by construction. A certificate of inspection and approval must be issued by the electrical inspector and it shall be unlawful to use, or permit the use of, or to supply electrical power for wiring, light or heat, in a building or structure unless the required certificate of inspection and approval has been obtained. 
(Code 1976, § 17-104) 
Sec. 5-89. - Contractor's license required. 
    All persons, firms or corporations performing any electrical work or electrical contracting in the city shall have a valid current state electrical contractor's license. 
(Code 1976, § 17-104) 
Cross reference- Licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 5-90. - Fee schedules. 
    Fee schedules will be set out from time to time and will be available at the city administrator's office. 
(Ord. No. 91-9, § 20, 10-15-91) 
Secs. 5-91-5-100. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 12; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 5-121. - Permission from council required; publication of notice of hearing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any used or secondhand building to be brought into the city from any point without the city or for any such building already within the city to be removed from its present location to any other location without special permission from the city council, which permission shall not be given in any case unless and until there shall have been a public hearing on written application of which hearing notice shall have been published once a week for four (4) weeks at the expense of the applicant in the official newspaper of the city, and once a week for two (2) of such four (4) weeks in the Atlanta Journal or Atlanta Constitution, which notice of such public hearing shall consist of a copy of such application for permission to remove such used or secondhand building, and such other information as may be required by the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 9-101) 
Sec. 5-122. - Notice of hearing after consideration of application. 
    The application required by section 5-121 shall be in writing addressed to the city council, and delivered to the city clerk at least five (5) days before the next regular meeting of the city council together with a deposit of the amount of money necessary to pay for the advertising cost, at which meeting of the city council such application shall be presented by the city clerk to the city council for its consideration, and if such application is found in order, and the city council determines that sufficient funds have been deposited with the city treasurer to pay the cost of advertising notice as hereinbefore provided, it shall fix a time and place for a hearing of such application and order publication of such notice stating the time and place when such application will be considered by the city council. 
(Code 1976, § 9-102) 
Sec. 5-123. - Information in application. 
    The application required by section 5-121 shall include the name of the applicant, the location and type of building applicant desires permission to remove, and the size and age of such building, the use to which it has been put, and the location to which applicant desires to remove it, the purpose for which such building is to be removed, and whether applicant is the owner of such building and the lot to which he desires to remove it, and such other information as the city council may require. 
(Code 1976, § 9-103) 
Sec. 5-124. - Unfit buildings not to be brought into city. 
    In no event will permission be granted to remove into the city any building which any government or governmental agency has found unfit for human habitation or which has been constructed of defective materials, or which has become defective from age, abuse, fire, or other cause. 
(Code 1976, § 9-104) 
Sec. 5-125. - Notice on lot when building moved into city. 
    It shall be unlawful for any house to be moved from a location without the city to a lot within the city unless there shall have been posted on the lot to which such house is to be moved a notice of the intention to move such house to such location, which notice shall be posted and shall conform to all rules, regulations and provisions relating to signs posted on lots to which houses are removed when they are moved from the right-of-way of expressways. 
(Code 1976, § 9-105) 
Sec. 5-126. - Permit from police department required; compliance with requirements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any house to be moved in, on, along or across any public street, alley, lane, road or way in the city, except in strict compliance with the provisions of this article, nor unless a special permit in writing has been issued for this purpose within the previous twenty-four (24) hours by the police department of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-106) 
Sec. 5-127. - Granting or refusing permit; deposits against loss or damage. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department of the city to grant the permit required by section 5-126 upon approval thereof by the fire department of the city, to which the police department shall submit the same for approval by the fire department, unless it appears that the moving of such house cannot or will not be done within twenty-four (24) hours from the time the permit would be issued, or that such moving will expose other persons or their property to great danger of injury or damage, or unless it appears that such moving will unreasonably congest traffic or work unnecessary inconvenience, delay, injury, damage or expense to others. If it appears that there is some reasonable prospect of injury or damage to others, but that refusal of such permit would work a more serious loss or injury to the mover or owner of such house, such permit may be issued upon deposit of an amount of money with the chief of police by the owner of the house or the applicant for the permit to indemnify and save anyone from loss or damage resulting from the moving; such amount of money shall be fixed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1976, § 9-107) 
Sec. 5-128. - Requests for permits. 
    Request for the permit required by section 5-126 shall be in writing filed with the chief of police of the city at least twenty-four (24) hours before it is desired to move such house and shall state the correct name and post office and street address of such mover, and the time when and the streets along or across which the house is to be moved. 
(Code 1976, § 9-108) 
Sec. 5-129. - Contents of permit. 
    The permit required by section 5-126 shall be signed by the chief of police or his duly authorized agent and shall set forth the time when and streets over or across which the house is to be moved. 
(Code 1976, § 9-109) 
Sec. 5-130. - Permitted during certain times on heavily traveled streets. 
    No house shall be moved over or across any heavily traveled street or street crossing, except between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. and then only so as to interfere with orderly and regular flow of traffic as little as possible. 
(Code 1976, § 9-110) 
Sec. 5-131. - Lighting outside area of structure. 
    No house shall be moved without at least one (1) red light at the top and one (1) at the bottom of each back corner to indicate the outside area of the street occupied by such house and likewise at each front corner of the house for the same purpose. Such lights shall be so located that the operator of any vehicle approaching such house from any direction can readily see how much of the street is being taken up by the moving of the house. All of the light shall be well-lighted at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 9-111) 
Sec. 5-132. - Stationing of guards required. 
    No house shall be moved in the city on any vehicle without a guard attending on either side and in front of and behind such moving house as the same moves along or across any street to give warning of its presence. The guards shall remain at a sufficient distance from the house to give ample warning of the presence of such house in the street in ample time to avoid any collision with any moving vehicle, train, locomotive or other moving object. 
(Code 1976, § 9-112) 
Sec. 5-133. - House mover's equipment. 
    No house mover shall commence or undertake to move any house in the city without adequate equipment in good working order. 
(Code 1976, § 9-113) 
Sec. 5-134. - Leaving a house unattended. 
    No house shall be left unattended on or partly on or across any public street, lane, alley or way in the city at any time of the day or night. 
(Code 1976, § 9-114) 
Sec. 5-135. - Notice of moving time and obstructed streets. 
    No house shall be moved on or across any public street, lane, road, alley, or way in the city without first giving the fire department of the city a written notice of the time of the moving and the names of the streets over, through, in or across which such house is to be moved in order that the fire department of the city may not be retarded or unnecessarily delayed in discharging its duties by an obstructed or congested street resulting from moving a house into, in or out of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-115) 
Sec. 5-136. - Moving prohibited under certain circumstances. 
    No house shall be moved nor shall any permit be granted for the removal of any house in the city at any time when it is not likely to be reasonably safe, or when it is reasonable to suppose there will be a street congestion for an unreasonable length of time on account of weather conditions or any other unusual conditions or circumstances, except upon such reasonable terms and conditions as may be prescribed by the joint chiefs of the police and fire departments of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-116) 
Sec. 5-137. - License to move over streets required; fee; exception. 
(a)  Any person who shall move a house or other building as a unit on, across or along any public street or highway within the city shall first pay a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to the city; provided, however, that the fee shall not be required of a church, hospital, or other eleemosynary institution. It shall be unlawful to move any house or building as aforesaid without first obtaining such license. 
(b)  When anyone duly authorized, desires to move a dwelling house or other building in two (2) or more sections, in, on, or across any public street or highway within the city, the license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first section, and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional section or unit to be moved which shall be paid in advance. 
(Code 1976, § 9-117) 
Sec. 5-138. - When necessitated by redevelopment; special permit. 
    Any person who shall desire to move any house or building, which shall be subject to destruction or displacement because of urban renewal or the construction of roads, streets, highways, hospitals or other public buildings, may do so by first obtaining a special permit to move such house or building from the city council, and by paying any license fee which may be required by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-118) 
Secs. 5-139-5-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUMBERING OF RESIDENCES, BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 5-151. - Required. 
(a)  Every residence, building, and business structure in the city shall be numbered in accordance with the general plan of numbering established for the city and shown on a map or maps set up for that purpose on file in the office of the city clerk in the city hall. 
(b)  The number appearing on the residence, building or business structure shall be that number assigned to it by the city or its authority. 
(Code 1976, § 7-101) 
Sec. 5-152. - Owner's responsibility. 
    The responsibility for placing the numbers on residences, buildings and structures is hereby placed upon the owner, and it shall be the owner's duty to see that such residence, building or structure has affixed to it the number assigned such residence, building or structure. 
(Code 1976, § 7-101) 
Sec. 5-153. - Size, location and material of numbers. 
    The owner or occupant of any house or building shall have the right to determine the size, material and location of such numbers except that the numbers shall be inscribed or affixed in a conspicuous place, and shall be of such size, color, or character that may be readily seen and read from the street by any person of ordinary vision. The numbers shall be so placed as to be plainly visible from the street and sidewalk, and if the residence, building or structure is of such distance from the street and sidewalk for the number not to be plainly visible on the building or structure, then the number shall be placed on a permanent post or elsewhere near the street and sidewalk. 
(Code 1976, § 7-101) 
Sec. 5-154. - City clerk to assign numbers. 
    The city clerk shall hereafter assign street numbers to all new residences, buildings or structures which may be erected in the city, such numbers to be assigned at the time a building permit is obtained. 
(Code 1976, § 7-101) 
Sec. 5-155. - Failure of owner to affix assigned number; assessment of cost by city. 
    Each owner of every residence, building or structure shall be given fifteen (15) days' notice by the city clerk as to the number assigned to such residence, building or structure, and upon the failure of any owner of such residence, building or structure to affix the number as prescribed above, the city shall affix such number and the cost thereof shall be assessed against the property owner and be collectable in the same manner that city taxes are collectable. 
(Code 1976, § 7-101) 
Sec. 5-156. - Penalty. 
    Any person, who fails to affix the number assigned by the city clerk within the time provided in section 5-155, or fails to affix it in the manner prescribed in section 5-153, shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be punished in accordance with section 1-17. 
(Code 1976, § 7-101) 
ARTICLE V. - WATER FLOW REQUIREMENTS; PLUMBING FIXTURES 

Sec. 5-157. - Building and housing. 
(a)  Purpose.
