(3)  It has an efficient gas washer of the venturi or impingement type with at least three (3) wet impingement surfaces; 
(4)  It has an adequate and approved induced draft fan; 
(5)  It has a secondary burner for use when necessary to destroy smoke or odors. 
(b)  Incinerators of a design capacity of more than fifty (50) tons per twenty-four (24) hours may be exempt from the provisions of subsection (a) of this section at the discretion of the health officer, provided that all other incinerator standards are met. 
(c)  No person shall make major alterations or repairs to an incinerator which will cost more than thirty (30) percent of the replacement cost of the incinerator, unless such major alterations or repairs will result in a final installation meeting the requirements of subsection (a) of this section. Any incinerator alteration or repair work costing more than fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be approved by the health officer prior to such alteration or repair. The owner shall be responsible for submitting such engineering data to the health officer as required to make clear the extent of the proposed alterations or repairs. 
(d)  No person shall install or construct an incinerator to be used for the disposal of combustible waste from fewer than fifty-one (51) families. 
(e)  Incinerators shall be maintained in good working order and shall be operated so as to: 
(1)  Maintain a temperature of at least eight hundred (800) degrees Fahrenheit in the primary combustion chamber; 
(2)  Comply with generally recognized good practices and all applicable provisions of this article; 
(3)  Make full and proper use of all components and appurtenances thereof. 
(f)  No person shall cause or allow to be emitted into the open air from any refuse-burning equipment any fly ash or other particulate matter in quantities exceeding 0.2 grains per standard cubic foot of flue gases, calculated to twelve (12) percent carbon dioxide for products of combustion and at sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit and at a gas pressure of 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute. This limitation shall apply when the refuse-burning equipment is operating at full load. In measuring emissions from refuse-burning equipment, the carbon dioxide produced by combustion of any liquid or gaseous fuels shall be excluded from the calculation to twelve (12) percent carbon dioxide. Tests to determine compliance with this section shall be performed as provided in section 8-30. 
(Code 1976, § 11-109) 
Sec. 8-25. - Emission of fly ash and other solid particulate matter from fuel-burning equipment. 
(a)  The emission or escape into the open air of fly ash or other particulate matter resulting from the combustion or incomplete combustion of fuel in any fuel-burning equipment or from any stack connected thereto, in quantities exceeding 0.85 pounds per one thousand (1,000) pounds of flue gases is prohibited and is hereby declared to be a nuisance. This limitation shall apply when the fuel-burning equipment is operating at full load and the excess air in the flue gases does not exceed fifty (50) percent. This section shall apply only to installations existing on or before the effective date of this article, provided that after five (5) years from the effective date of this article all fuel-burning equipment shall comply with the provisions of subsection (b) of this section regardless of the date on which it was built, altered or reconstructed. 
(b)  The emission or escape into the open air of fly ash or other particulate matter resulting from the combustion or incomplete combustion of fuel in any fuel-burning equipment in quantities exceeding the limits specified in Figure 1 for the size of equipment involved is prohibited. These limitations shall apply when the fuel-burning equipment is operating at the maximum design heat input rating. 
(c)  The heat input rating of any unit discharging to a single stack shall be the maximum design input rating, including both heat available from burning of fuel and any sensible heat from materials introduced into the combustion zone at temperatures above the ambient air temperature. When two (2) or more fuel-burning units are connected to a single stack, the combined fuel-burning capacity of all units connected shall be used to determine the BTU input for establishing the maximum allowable emission. When one (1) fuel-burning unit is connected to two (2) or more stacks, the heat input of the equipment shall be the criterion for the maximum allowable total emission from all stacks combined. 
(d)  This section shall apply to all fuel-burning installations built hereafter or any such installations hereafter altered, reconstructed or repaired at a cost exceeding thirty (30) percent of the replacement cost of the installation. This section shall apply to all fuel-burning installations after five (5) years from the effective date of this article, regardless of the date on which they were built, altered, reconstructed or repaired. 
(Code 1976, § 11-110) 
Editor's note- The notation "Figure 1" referred to in subsection (b) of this section is not printed herein but is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 8-26. - Internal combustion engines. 
(a)  No person shall cause, allow or permit the emission of visible air contaminants in excess of that permitted by section 8-20 from the internal combustion engine of portable or stationary equipment for longer than ten (10) consecutive seconds, or from the engine of a motor vehicle while the engine is idling or after the vehicle has moved more than one hundred (100) yards from the place where the vehicle was started in motion. The provisions of this section shall not apply to engines of less than seventy-five-cubic-inch displacement. 
(b)  The owner of any automobile or truck or other vehicle which was required by federal law or regulation to be fitted with approved pollution-control devices at the time of manufacture, shall have such devices on his vehicle and shall maintain and operate them whenever such vehicle is used in this city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-111) 
Sec. 8-27. - Process emission. 
    The maximum allowable emission of particulate matter from any source except fuel-burning or refuse-burning equipment shall be determined from Table 1. 
(Code 1976, § 11-112) 
Editor's note- The "Table 1" referred to in this section is not printed herein but is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 8-28. - Flue placement and height. 
(a)  The point of discharge of flues and ducts exhausting air contaminants must be at least eight (8) feet above any air intake, roof, or combustible materials within twenty-five (25) feet, and must not be closer than twenty-five (25) feet to any air intake. 
(b)  Flue height shall be determined by engineering considerations and shall be higher than existing buildings adjacent thereto. Where new construction is higher than and is adjacent to an existing stack, the cost of correction shall be borne by the owner of the new building. 
(Code 1976, § 11-113) 
Sec. 8-29. - Sulfur oxides. 
(a)  No person shall cause, allow or permit any emission of sulfur oxides which results in ground-level concentrations at any point in excess of 0.5 parts per million by volume for a continuous period of more than one (1) hour, and the average concentration shall not exceed 0.2 parts per million by volume of sulfur oxides in any twenty-four-hour period. These limitations shall not apply to ground-level concentrations occurring on the premises on which such emission occurs. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a) above, no person shall cause, permit or allow the emission of gas containing sulfur oxides in excess of two thousand (2,000) parts per million by volume at the point of discharge. All sampling of exhaust gases shall be conducted following techniques designated by or approved by the health officer. For purposes of this section, all sulfur present in gaseous compounds and containing oxygen shall be deemed to be present as sulfur dioxide and analyses of samples taken to determine the amount of sulfur dioxide in exhaust gases shall be made as specified by the health officer. The test for determining compliance with this section shall be for at least thirty (30) representative consecutive minutes or ninety (90) percent of the time of actual source operation, whichever is less. 
(Code 1976, § 11-114) 
Sec. 8-30. - Responsibility for testing. 
    The person responsible for any fuel-burning, refuse-burning or process equipment shall, upon written request of the health officer, promptly make or have made at his own expense, tests to determine the quantity of any specified effluent emitted into the open air from such equipment or from associated emission-control devices and promptly report results of such tests to the health officer. Where applicable, such tests shall be conducted in accordance with methods prescribed in the publication Power Test Code #27 for Dust Separation Apparatus of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, or with methods deemed equivalent to test for a specific air contaminant as required by the health officer, and such test shall be performed by persons meeting the qualifications recommended by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the American Society for Testing Materials. 
(Code 1976, § 11-115) 
Sec. 8-31. - Odors in the ambient air. 
    No person shall permit the emission of objectionable odors from any source under his control. Diesel engines equipped, maintained and operated so as to minimize objectionable odors are exempt from this provision. 
(Code 1976, § 11-116) 
Sec. 8-32. - Materials handling; construction and demolition. 
(a)  Any material which may create air pollution as the result of dispersal during transport shall be so treated prior to transport, or so enclosed during transport as to effectively prevent air pollution during transport. 
(b)  Effective measures shall be employed to prevent air pollution resulting from the dispersal of materials from premises, from stockpiles or from accumulations incidental to manufacture, handling or storage. 
(c)  Effective measures shall be applied to prevent air pollution resulting from the demolition of buildings or equipment, the clearing of land, the preparation of sites for construction, or from the construction of buildings or the installation of equipment. 
(Code 1976, § 11-117) 
Sec. 8-33. - Air pollution prohibited. 
(a)  The discharge from any source of air contaminants resulting in air pollution in excess of the limits stipulated in this article is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as authorizing or legalizing the creation or maintenance of a nuisance or the violation of any other county regulation or municipal ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 11-118) 
Sec. 8-34. - Registration. 
(a)  Timely notice shall be given the health officer before any fuel-burning equipment, refuse-burning equipment or process equipment is hereafter installed or extensively altered. Such notice shall be supplemented by such plans, specifications and other information as the health officer deems necessary to assess the potential effect of such equipment on air pollution or to determine whether it would comply with this article. 
(b)  Subsection (a) above shall not apply to fuel-burning equipment used for heating dwellings of fewer than three (3) families, to equipment for burning gas, No. 1 or No. 2 fuel oil or to internal combustion engines. 
(Code 1976, § 11-119) 
Sec. 8-35. - Right of entry; examination and access to information. 
    The person in charge of any premises subject to the provisions of this article shall permit access of the health officer to all parts of the premises or facilities thereon to determine compliance with this article, and such person shall permit the health officer to collect and preserve evidence of all facts pertinent to such determination. Such person shall upon official request, and for official use only, make available such data and records as the health officer may require to enforce this article or to determine compliance therewith. 
(Code 1976, § 11-120) 
Sec. 8-36. - Notice of violation. 
    Should the health officer find the violation of any provision of this article to exist, he shall give notice of such violation in writing to the person responsible, specifying the nature of the violation and a reasonable time for correcting it. Delivery of such notice may be effected by mail or by personal delivery. 
(Code 1976, § 11-121) 
Chapter 9 - LICENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference- Authority to levy and provide for the collection of license fees and taxes on privileges, occupations, trades and professions, § 1-103; authority to regulate or prohibit junk dealers, § 1-103(17); authority to regulate and control the conduct of peddlers, § 1-103(18); authority to license and regulate fortunetelling, § 1-103(19).

State Law reference- Revenue and taxation, OCGA Title 48; specific business and occupation taxes, OCGA Title 48, Ch. 13. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Definitions. 
    The definitions used in section 9-42 shall likewise apply to this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(1), 10-7-80) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 9-2. - License required. 
    Every business in this city, including any business located outside the city but engaged in business within the city, is hereby required to have a business license from the city for the privilege of engaging in a business, profession or occupation within the corporate limits, unless city licensing is prohibited under state law or the activity is exempted by this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(2), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-3. - License application. 
(a)  Every person required to procure a license under the provisions of this article shall submit an application for the license to the administrator, which application shall conform to the requirements of this article in addition to any other provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, each application shall be a written statement upon forms provided by the city and submitted before February first of each year or ten (10) days prior to opening a new business. 
(c)  Each application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and home address of the applicant if an individual, or home office address if a corporation or partnership; 
(2)  Place where the proposed business is to be located; 
(3)  Kind an class of business to be carried on as defined in section 9-42; 
(4)  Names and home addresses of the partners, if a partnership; 
(5)  Names and home addresses of the officers and directors, if a corporation; and 
(6)  The amount of gross revenue for the preceding year and number of employees of the business for the third quarter of the preceding year and any other information as may be required by the administrator for the purpose of determining the amount of any business taxes to be collected under this chapter. 
(d)  Each application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant if an individual, or by a partner if a partnership, or by an officer if a corporation. 
(e)  All information furnished or secured under the authority of this article shall be kept in strict confidence by the city, shall not be subject to public inspection, and shall be utilized solely by the officers of the city responsible for administering the provisions of this article and the city's business taxes. 
(f)  False statements on any application for a license shall be grounds for immediate revocation of the license or denial of the application. 
(g)  An application, license and registration fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall accompany the application along with any other fees as may be required elsewhere. This fee shall be nonrefundable. 
(h)  Transient and temporary businesses are not required to pay the fee required by this section but shall pay the business tax under section 9-53. No license granted these businesses shall be valid after one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(2), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-4. - Administration. 
    The administrator shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the application for and issuance of business licenses and the regulation of businesses under this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(4), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-5. - Rules and regulations. 
    The administrator shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the city and the state or the Constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. These rules and regulations shall become effective upon adoption by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(5), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-6. - Duties of administrator. 
    The administrator, or an authorized representative, shall have, among others, the following duties: 
(1)  To prepare and provide the necessary forms for the registration and application for a business license and for the submission of any required information as may be necessary to properly administer and enforce the provisions of this article; 
(2)  To issue to each person a business license within a reasonable time after the payment of the license fee assessed and any business taxes levied in this chapter; provided, however, where under other ordinances of the city, permits, certifications, and compliance with enumerated conditions are required for the operation of the business, the administrator shall not issue a business license until the applicant exhibits to the administrator the obtained permits, certifications, and compliance. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(6), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-7. - Duration of license. 
    Any license referred to in this article shall automatically expire on December thirty-first of the year of its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(7), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-8. - Procedure for issuance of license. 
(a)  When any provision of this article provides for the review of an application for a license by a city officer designated therein, the administrator shall forward a copy of the application to that officer. The officer charged with the duty of reviewing the application shall make a recommendation thereon, favorable or otherwise, and shall return the recommendation to the administrator after receiving a copy of the application. 
(b)  Upon the receipt of the recommendation of the reviewing officer as provided in this section, or upon the receipt of the application if no reviewing officer is designated, the administrator shall forward the recommendation and application to the mayor and council for consideration and action at its next regularly scheduled public meeting if review by the mayor and council is required. 
(c)  No license shall be issued to any applicant whose place of business is not in full compliance with all minimum standard building codes adopted by the city. 
(d)  Upon the express approval of the mayor and council when so required or otherwise upon a determination by the administrator that the application is in order and all requirements have been met, the administrator shall issue a business license to the applicant therefor, which license shall state the nature of the business authorized and bear the date of issuance and the signature of the administrator. 
(e)  The granting of a business license under any provision of this chapter shall be deemed a privilege only and nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as granting any person whose business is subject to municipal regulation any legal right to engage in that business. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(8), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-9. - Display of license or registration. 
    All persons shall exhibit and display the license or registration issued to them under this chapter in some conspicuous place near the primary entrance of their business establishment at which address the license or registration was issued. Any transient or nonresident person doing business within the city shall carry the license or registration either upon his person or in any vehicle or other conveyance which is used in the business and the person shall exhibit the same to any authorized enforcement officer of the city when so requested. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(9), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-10. - Renewal of licenses. 
    Unless otherwise provided, each licensee shall make a written application for renewal on forms supplied by the administrator no later than February first of each calendar year, which application shall contain substantially the same information as the initial application. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(10), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-11. - Revocation; suspension of licenses. 
(a)  Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license, the city license to deal in that product shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any action by the mayor and council or any municipal officer. 
(b)  Whenever a holder of a license granted in this article by the mayor and council shall fail to open for business the establishment referred to in the license and begin the sale of products or product authorized by the license within six (6) months from the date of issuance of the license, or whenever a holder of a license shall begin the operation of a business and sale of the product or products as authorized in the license but shall fail to operate the business for a period of six (6) consecutive months, the holder shall automatically forfeit his license. The license holder shall receive notice, a hearing and all other due process as required in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  No license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any person under this article shall be revoked, except for due cause as defined in this section and after a hearing and upon the prior seven-day written notice to the holder of the license of the time, place and purpose of the hearing and a statement of the charge upon which the hearing shall be held. 
(d)  When circumstances warrant the immediate cessation of any business activity, the administrator shall have the authority to summarily and immediately suspend the activity upon written notice to the holder of the license for the activity. A suspension shall be valid, until a revocation proceeding may be held, up to a maximum of thirty (30) days. 
(e)  Due cause for the revocation of a license shall consist of the violation of any laws or ordinances regulating the businesses, or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating the businesses, or for the violation of any state or federal law, or for the violation of or conflict with any city ordinance other than traffic ordinances. 
(f)  The hearing shall be conducted before the mayor and council by the administrator or the city attorney. 
(g)  The mayor and council may, if it finds this chapter to have been violated by the licensee, his agent, or employee, or a license to have been issued in conflict with state law or this Code, revoke the license in its entirety, suspend the same for a specified period of time, place the licensee on probation, or place other conditions thereon as the mayor and council may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(11), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-12. - Change of address. 
    Any person moving from one (1) location to another shall notify the administrator of the move and the new address in writing on a form provided by the administrator no later than the day of moving. The same business license will be valid at the new location if the new location conforms to the zoning regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(12), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-13. - Licenses not transferable. 
    Business licenses shall not be transferable and a transfer of ownership shall be considered in the same light as the termination of the business and the establishment of a new business; therefore, a new license fee shall be required for the new owner of the business. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(13), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-14. - Branch, multiple, or joint businesses. 
    Any business with multiple locations or branches and any business which engages in several different businesses shall be deemed to be separate businesses for purposes of this article with the requirement of separate licenses or registrations for each. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(14), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-15. - Subsequent amendments. 
    This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the city to assess, levy and collect any of the license fees prescribed. The payment of any license fee provided for in this chapter shall not be construed to deny the right of the city to assess, levy and collect any of the license fees prescribed. The payment of any license fee provided for in this chapter shall not be construed as prohibiting the assessment, levy or collection of additional license fees upon the same person. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103A(15), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-16. - Construction permits. 
    Any person obtaining a permit for grading, landscaping, trenching; or construction, repair, or demolition of any structure; or any other work which may require an inspection by a city inspector shall, at the time of making application for such permit, list the name and address of the person or business securing such permit, and the names and addresses of all contractors and subcontractors who shall perform any service in connection with the work for which such permit is sought. If, at the time of applying for such permit, any of such contractors and subcontractors have not been employed or contracted with, then upon the employment or contracting with such contractors or subcontractors, and before the performance of any service by same, such person shall immediately list his name and address on the form to be secured from the administrator and shall file same with the administrator. Any person obtaining such permit for any of the services in this section which require an inspection by a city inspector shall, prior to beginning the service, pay the appropriate inspection or permit fee as determined by the administrator in accordance with applicable ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(1), 10-7-80) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 9-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-04, § 1, adopted June 21, 2016, repealed former § 9-17 which pertained to salespersons, solicitors, and peddlers; registration, and derived from Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(2), adopted Oct. 7, 1980. 
Sec. 9-18. - Private detectives, private detective agencies; applications; licensing; regulations and prohibited activities. 
(a)  Definition. Private detectives or private detective agencies are defined as those following the business or vocation pursued by all persons or agencies making investigations for others when the investigations involve the conduct, life or affairs of the persons investigated. These terms shall not include lawyers and accountants in the course of their practice or incident thereto. 
(b)  Applications for licensing. 
(1)  Any person who shall desire to engage in the business of a private detective or detective agency shall first make application to the chief of police and the application shall contain the following information: 
a.  The name of the applicant, his age and present address; 
b.  The places the applicant has resided in the past ten (10) years; 
c.  The places the applicant has been employed for the past ten (10) years; 
d.  The marital status of the applicant; 
e.  Information concerning the experience the applicant has had in detective work; 
f.  Information concerning the applicant's criminal record, if any; 
g.  The names and addresses of two (2) residents of the state for character purposes; 
h.  The names and addresses of two (2) credit references; and 
i.  Any other information the chief of police deems pertinent. 
(2)  The application shall be accompanied by a photograph not more than twelve (12) months old of the applicant. 
(3)  The application shall be made under oath and the giving of false information shall result in the revocation of any license issued in reliance thereon. 
(c)  Processing the application. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to accept each application presented to him as set out above. The chief shall then investigate the character, integrity and competence of the applicant. The chief shall then submit a written report to the city administrator together with recommendations for the issuance or denial of the license. The city administrator shall report to the mayor and council at the next regular meeting. The mayor and council shall determine the merits of the matter and either direct the issuance of the license or deny the same. 
(d)  Age of applicants. No person shall be granted a license as a private detective unless that person has attained twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(e)  Separate license for each private detective. A separate license must be obtained for each person engaged in activities described herein even though that person is an employee of another person duly licensed under this section. 
(f)  Business tax. The annual business tax for each person shall be as set forth in article II of this chapter. 
(g)  Annual licensing. Any person wishing to engage in the business of private detective or private detective agency shall make the initial application, pay the license fee and business tax and be granted an initial license prior to beginning any detective work in the city. Initial licenses shall expire on December thirty-first of the year in which they are granted. Thereafter the person shall make application for continuance of the business in the city annually on or before December fifteenth of each year for a license for the coming year. The procedure on the application shall be followed as was followed on the original application. 
(h)  Police supervision. All licensed private detectives shall be subject to supervision and direction by police officers of the city. 
(i)  Regulations and prohibited activities. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to allow any person licensed hereunder to violate the laws of the United States, the state, or the city, nor shall any person licensed hereunder violate the civil or constitutional rights of any person nor shall any person licensed under this article use the license, credentials, or position to collect money or obtain property from any person. Should the city administrator receive a complaint from any person that a licensee has violated any provision of this section, he shall within thirty (30) days of receiving the complaint set up a hearing before the mayor and council and give the person against whom the complaint was made fifteen (15) days' notice of the hearing. At the hearing the mayor or, in his absence, the mayor pro tem shall preside. Both the complaining party and the person against whom the complaint is made shall be entitled to counsel of their choice; to subpoena and call witnesses; and be heard on the merits. Witnesses shall testify under oath and be subject to penalty for perjury if false testimony is given. The purpose of the hearing shall be to determine the fitness of the person against whom the complaint is made to continue to operate as a private detective in the city. After hearing evidence from both sides, the mayor and council shall vote "yes" or "no" to continue the license. If a majority of the council present and voting, vote "no," the license shall be thereupon revoked. No person whose license has been revoked shall be allowed to reapply for a license within twelve (12) months of the revocation. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(3), 10-7-80) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Operators of private detective businesses and private security businesses, OCGA § 43-38-1; restrictions on local granting of business license, OCGA § 43-38-14.1. 
Sec. 9-19. - Garage sales and rummage sales; regulation of and license fee required. 
    Sales commonly known as garage sales or rummage sales conducted on residential property shall be subject to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  These sales shall be conducted only by the owner or tenant of the residential property use. 
(2)  No such sales shall be conducted for a longer period than seventy-two (72) hours consecutively in any six-month period on one (1) residential lot. 
(3)  No wares, goods, or merchandise shall be advertised or offered for sale or swap, or given away except goods, wares, and merchandise owned by the property owner or the tenant conducting the sale. 
(4)  No goods, wares, or merchandise shall be purchased by the owner or tenant for the purpose of selling, swapping, or giving away same at such a sale. 
(5)  Any person desiring to conduct such a sale shall notify the administrator of the intent at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the time the sale is to begin. The administrator or his authorized representatives shall issue a license to the person to conduct a sale upon the payment of a license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) if the applicant otherwise meets the requirements of this section. This fee shall be in lieu of any other fees or business taxes in this chapter. 
(6)  Sales for religious or charitable purposes only shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale or rummage sale without first obtaining a license as described herein or in such a manner as to violate any of the provisions of this section and the administrator is authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(4), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-20. - Bail bonds. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of a business license to write or post bail bond the applicant shall be required to submit cash, cashier's check or money order to be deposited in an escrow account with a value of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). The money shall be contingent upon the payment of the sums due the city on forfeited bonds written by the applicant. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to write or post bail bonds in the city and engage in the bail bonds business, unless and until that person has obtained a license as provided in this chapter and has posted an approved bond as provided in this section. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of all persons lawfully engaged in business as bail bondsmen to file with the revenue collection officer a list of the names of all their employees, with their home address and home telephone number. Changes in the list of employees, adding new employees, must be filed with the revenue collection officer within three (3) days from the date of any such change. All new employees shall undergo a background investigation to be performed by the department of public safety. Every current employee shall undergo an annual background investigation to be performed by the department of public safety. A twenty-five dollar ($25.00) investigation fee shall be charged for each new and renewal investigation. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(5), 10-7-80; Ord. No. 95-8, § 3, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 2010-20B, § 1, 7-20-10) 
Sec. 9-21. - Liability insurance required for operators of certain amusement devices. 
    All persons shall, prior to operating an amusement device where human beings are conveyed, obtain from the city permit. Upon requesting a permit the applicant must show evidence of personal liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each accident plus ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for property damages and provide the name of an agent for service domiciled in the county. 
(Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(6), 10-7-80) 
Sec. 9-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-04, § 2, adopted June 21, 2016, repealed former § 9-22 which pertained to religious and charitable soliciting, and derived from Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103B(7), adopted Oct. 7, 1980; and Ord. No. 92-7, adopted July 21, 1992. 
Sec. 9-23. - Pawnbrokers. 
(a)  License required. Each pawnbroker doing business within this municipality shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. 
(b)  Fee established. The annual business license fee for each pawnbroker doing business in this city shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fee is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  Application. In addition to all other information required of an applicant in this chapter all those applying for pawnbroker's licenses shall include in their application a complete record of all arrests and convictions against the applicant and every partner, officer, or director of the applicant for violations of any and all laws and ordinances of the city, state, or federal government. 
(d)  Procedure for issuance. The city clerk shall forward all applications for pawnbroker's licenses to the chief of police within forty-eight (48) hours of the time of receipt of the application. The police chief shall review the application and make a recommendation thereon, favorable or otherwise, and shall return such recommendation to the city clerk within seven (7) days after receiving a copy of the application. The city clerk shall then forward the application and recommendation to the mayor and council for consideration and action at its next regular scheduled public meeting. 
(e)  Limitation on issuance. No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the offense of receiving stolen goods or of burglary or robbery. 
(f)  Records. Each pawnbroker licensed under the terms of this chapter shall furnish to the police chief each week a list of every article pledged with him or sold to him during the previous week, giving a full and accurate description of the article, from whom it was received, and the hour of the day received. 
(g)  Minors. No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with a minor, nor shall a pawnbroker's license be issued to a minor, nor shall a pawnbroker employ a minor to assist him in his business. 
(h)  Stolen goods. It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged with him, or which is sought to be pledged with him, if he shall have reason to believe that the article was stolen or lost and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article. 
(Code 1976, § 15-204) 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, OCGA § 44-12-130 et seq. 
Sec. 9-24. - Used car dealers. 
(a)  License required. Any used car or used motor vehicle dealer, as such terms are defined in OCGA section 43-47-2, who does business within this municipality shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. 
(b)  Fee established. The annual business license fee for each used car or used motor vehicle dealer doing business in the city shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fee is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  Procedure for issuance. The city clerk shall forward all applications for used car dealer's licenses to the chief of police within forty-eight (48) hours of the time of receipt of the application. The police chief shall review the application and make a recommendation thereon, favorable or otherwise, and shall return such recommendation to the city clerk within seven (7) days after receiving a copy of the application. The city clerk shall then forward the application and recommendation to the mayor and council for consideration and action at its next regular scheduled public meeting. 
(d)  Restriction on issuance. No license under this section shall be issued to any applicant who has not been licensed by the state board of registration of used car dealers. 
(e)  Records. Each used car or used motor vehicle dealer licensed hereunder shall keep a record of all motor vehicles offered for sale, exchange, or disposal to the public, which record shall show the make of the motor vehicle, the year of its manufacture, its serial number, and its engine number, and which record shall always be kept available for the chief of police or any patrolman or police officer within the city and open to his inspection at any time. It shall be the further duty of every such person to immediately report to the chief of police the presence in his place of business of any motor vehicle on which the serial or engine number has been defaced or altered. 
(f)  Inspections. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make inspections from time to time for the purpose of seeing that the records required in this section are being kept. 
(g)  Exceptions. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to apply to any individual making an isolated sale of his own vehicle. 
(Code 1976, § 15-205) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate and license used car dealers, OCGA § 43-47-14. 
Sec. 9-25. - Junk dealers and junkyards. 
(a)  License required. Each junk dealer, as such term is defined in this section, who does business within the city, shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them herein: 
    Business premises or premises means the area of a junkyard as described in a junk dealer's license or application for license, as provided for in this section. 
    Junk means old iron, steel, brass, copper, tin, lead, or other base metals; old cordage, ropes, rags, fibers or fabrics; old rubber; old bottles or other glass; bones; wastepaper and other waste or discarded material which might be prepared to be used again in some form; and motor vehicles, no longer used as such, to be used for scrap metal or stripping of parts; but "junk" shall not include materials or objects accumulated by a person as by-products, waste, or scraps from the operation of his own business, or materials or objects held and used by a manufacturer as an integral part of his own manufacturing processes. 
    Junk dealer means a person who operates a junkyard, as defined below, within the city. 
    Junkyard means a yard, lot, or place, covered or uncovered, outdoors or in an enclosed building, containing junk as defined above, upon which occurs one or more acts of buying, keeping, dismantling, processing, selling, or offering for sale any such junk, in whole units or by parts, for a business or commercial purpose, whether or not the proceeds from such act or acts are to be used for charity. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
(c)  Application. Application for license under this section shall be made as provided in section 9-1, except that such application shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  Trade names used during the previous five (5) years by the applicant and each person signing the application, along with the locations of prior establishments; 
(2)  Names and addresses of employees of each person signing the application during the previous five (5) years; 
(3)  Name, residence address, and telephone number of each person employed or intended to be employed in the business as of the time the application is filed; 
(4)  A sketch of the actual premises to be used in connection with the business, giving distances in feet and showing adjoining roads, property lines, buildings, and uses; and 
(5)  A description of the materials with which any buildings to be used in connection with the licensed business are or are to be made; a sketch giving distances, showing the location of such buildings on the business premises; and a diagram or plan giving distances and heights, showing floors, exits, entrances, windows, ventilators, and walls. 
(d)  Review of application. No action on any application for a license to operate a junkyard shall be taken by the city council until the planning commission has reviewed such application and forwarded its recommendation thereof to the mayor and council. 
(e)  Fee established. The annual business license fee for each junk dealer doing business in this municipality shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fee is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(f)  General operating requirements. The following general operating requirements shall apply to all junk dealers licensed in accordance with the provisions of this section: 
(1)  The junkyard, together with things kept therein, shall at all times be maintained in a sanitary condition; 
(2)  No space not covered by the license shall be used in the licensed business; 
(3)  No water shall be allowed to stand in any place on the premises in such manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes; 
(4)  No weeds shall be permitted to attain a height of more than six (6) inches; 
(5)  No garbage or other waste liable to give off a foul odor or attract vermin shall be kept on the premises; nor shall any refuse of any kind be kept on the premises, unless such refuse is junk as defined in this section and is in use in the licensed business; 
(6)  No junk shall be allowed to rest upon or protrude over any public street, walkway, or curb, or become scattered or blown off the business premises; 
(7)  Junk shall be stored in piles not exceeding ten (10) feet in height and shall be arranged so as to permit easy access to all such junk for firefighting purposes; 
(8)  No combustible material of any kind not necessary or beneficial to the licensed business shall be kept on the premises; nor shall the premises be allowed to become a fire hazard; 
(9)  Gasoline and oil shall be removed from any scrapped engines or vehicles on the premises; 
(10)  No noisy processing of junk or other noisy activity shall be carried on in connection with the licensed business on any Sunday, Christmas, Thanksgiving, or at any time between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.; 
(11)  The area on the premises where junk is kept, other than indoors, shall be enclosed, except for entrances and exits, with a solid vertical wall, planted screen or similar opaque screen or fence of a minimum height of six (6) feet measured from ground level. The fence or wall shall not contain any poster or advertising of any kind excepting one (1) sign of the licensee not exceeding the size set forth in the sign ordinance of the city. Entrances and exits shall not be wider or more numerous than reasonably necessary for the conduct of the licensed business; 
(12)  The licensee shall permit inspection of the business premises by any police officer at any reasonable time; 
(13)  No junkyard shall be allowed to become a nuisance; nor shall any junkyard be operated in such manner as to become injurious to the health, safety, or welfare of the community or of any residents close by. 
(g)  Records. Each acquisition of junk shall be recorded in a permanent type register kept on the business premises, giving the name and residence address of the person from whom the acquisition was made, a description of the junk acquired, and the date of the transaction. Such data shall be held available for inspection by any police officer. 
(h)  Stolen goods. Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles, or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall upon demand produce such article or thing to any member of the police department for examination. 
(i)  Vehicles. Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the names and addresses of the owner and proprietor thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 15-206) 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit junk dealers, § 1-103(17). 
State Law reference- Junk dealers, OCGA § 43-22-1 et seq. 
Sec. 9-26. - Auctions. 
(a)  License required. Each person who desires to conduct an auction within this municipality shall be required to obtain a license therefor from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. 
(b)  Fee established. The business license fee for each auction licensed under this section shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fee is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  Application. Application for a license under this section shall be made as provided in section 9-3, except that such application shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  A statement setting forth when, where, and for how long the auction sale will be conducted; 
(2)  A certified copy of the state auctioneer's license of the person who is to conduct the auction. 
(d)  Bond. Every applicant for a license under this section shall submit with the city clerk cash, cashier's check or money order to be deposited in an escrow account in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), conditioned that the applicant, if issued a license hereunder will comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of this city and the statutes of this state regulating and concerning auctions and auctioneers, will render true and strict amounts of all his sales to any person or persons employing him to make the same, will not practice any fraud or deceit upon bidders or purchasers of property from him at any auction sale or suffer or permit any person in his employ to practice any such fraud or deceit, and will pay all damages which may be sustained by any person by reference of any fraud, deceit, negligence, or other wrongful act on the part of the licensee, his agent, or employees in the conduct of any auction or in the exercise of the calling of auctioneer. A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state which conforms to the above requirements may be permitted by the city clerk in his discretion in lieu of a bond. Bonds will be held by the city for a minimum period of twelve (12) months after business is terminated. 
(e)  Cappers, boosters, or by-bidders. It shall be unlawful for any person to act or to employ another in any auction sale as a by-bidder or what is sometimes known as a "capper" or "booster," or to make or to accept any false or misleading bid, or to pretend to buy or sell any article sold or offered for sale at such auction. 
(f)  Exemption. Nothing in this section shall be held to apply to auction sales conducted by trustees or referees in bankruptcy; executors, administrators, receivers, or other public officers acting under judicial process, nor to the sale of real property, at auction. 
(Code 1976, § 15-207; Ord. No. 2010-20B, § 2, 7-20-10) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate and license auctioneers, OCGA § 43-6-25.1. 
Sec. 9-27. - Special event tents. 
    Any person, firm or corporation is allowed the use of an on-premise special event tent for a special use or event, such as, but not limited, grand openings, seasonal sales, promotional sales, liquidation going out of business sales, fire sales or free promotions, only under the following conditions and requirements: 
(a)  No tent shall be erected or used except in connection with a permanent structure and providing a paved parking area. The site must comply with the zoning ordinance of the City of Union City and all rules and regulations thereof. 
(b)  The maximum size allowance for such tents shall not exceed sixty (60) feet by one hundred twenty (120) feet. 
(c)  The maximum number of special event tent permits to be issued to a single business location or parcel shall be two (2) per year for a period of time not to exceed sixteen (16) days for each issuance. 
(d)  All special event tents must be approved by the Union City Fire Marshal. 
(e)  Special exceptions may be granted by the mayor and council provided the request is presented to them ten (10) days prior to the date of the event or use. 
(f)  Permit fees: No permit shall be issued until the exact dimension and area and location of tent has been filed with the zoning administrator and fees have been paid as provided. 
Tent Area Fees   1 to 25 square feet $ 10.00  26 to 50 square feet 20.00  51 to 100 square feet 30.00 101 to 200 square feet 40.00 201 to 300 square feet 50.00 301 to 500 square feet 60.00 501 to 700 square feet 200.00 701 and up 300.00  
(Ord. No. 90-7, 4-19-90) 
Sec. 9-28. - Solid waste handlers; licenses. 
(a)  Definition. For the purposes of this section, the definition of solid waste and solid waste handling shall be the same as defined within section 7-2. 
(b)  License required. No person shall conduct business as a solid waste handler within the city without first obtaining a business license from the city administrator in the manner specified in this section. 
(c)  Fee established. The annual business license fee for each solid waste handler doing business within the city shall be set from time to time as deemed appropriate by the governing body. Current schedules of such license fees shall be kept on file in the city administrator's office. 
(d)  Application. All persons desiring to obtain a license under this section shall submit an initial written application, and a renewal annually thereafter, to the city for such privilege upon forms to be approved by the governing body. Such applications shall state the name and address of the applicant, the location of the business, the service area of the business, proof of compliance with state license laws and with city ordinances (particularly with Chapter 7 of the city code), proof of ownership of county license, if required, and such other information as may be required by the governing body. 
(e)  Letters of assurance required. 
(1)  In addition to the information required of an applicant for a solid waste handler's license, each initial and renewal application must also include a letter of solid waste disposal assurance from a state-permitted solid waste disposal facility. The letter must be on the letterhead of the entity owning the disposal facility and must contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of the solid waste disposal facility to be utilized by the applicant. 
b.  Name, address and telephone number of the entity to whom the state permit is issued. 
c.  Name, title and telephone number of the authorized individual or company official signing the assurance letter on behalf of the disposal facility. 
d.  Estimated life of permitted capacity remaining at current and projected rates of waste disposal in tons or cubic yards. 
e.  A statement that sufficient disposal capacity exists to accommodate the solid waste handling applicant over the expected remaining life of the disposal facility based on the remaining capacity and the amount of waste received at the disposal facility. 
f.  A statement that appropriate arrangements are in place such that the disposal facility will reserve a portion of its capacity on behalf of the solid waste handler license applicant. 
(2)  In the event the proposed disposal facility has a remaining life of less than ten (10) years, the license application must include additional letters of solid waste disposal assurance containing the above-described information such that a total of ten (10) years of disposal assurance is provided. 
(f)  Compliance with section. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, control, manage or own any business which handles solid waste within the city without having complied with the provisions of this section. Noncompliance shall subject such a violator to the revocation of any business license which may have been issued pursuant to this section, and to a fine and/or imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 92-14, 12-15-92) 
Secs. 9-29-9-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 1995 deleted Art. II, §§ 9-41-9-59, in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as herein set out. Former §§ 9-41-9-59 derived from Ord. No. 80-8, § 4-103(1), (3)-(19), adopted Oct. 7, 1980; Ord. No. 81-8, adopted Nov. 3, 1981; and Ord. No. 89-23, adopted Oct. 3, 1989. 
Charter reference- Authority to levy and collect license fees and taxes on privileges, occupations, trades and professions, § 1-103(2). 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; taxation and finance, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Specific business and occupation taxes, OCGA Title 48, Ch. 13. 

Sec. 9-41. - Occupation tax required for business dealings within the city. 
    For the year 1996 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation from a location in Union City, Georgia (whether the main office or main place of business, or residence, be within or without Union City, Georgia or the State of Georgia), shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-42. - Construction of terms; definitions. 
(a)  Construction of terms. Wherever the term "City of Union City" is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean "Union City, Georgia"; wherever the term "city" is used herein, it shall be construed to mean "Union City, Georgia". 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this article: 
(1)  Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
(2)  Gross receipts. 
a.  Gross receipts means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without limitation to the following: 
1.  Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; 
2.  Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets, or instruments of indebtedness; 
3.  Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods, or services; 
4.  Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and 
5.  Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty, or dividend income. 
b.  Gross receipts shall not include the following: 
1.  Sales, use, or excise tax; 
2.  Sales returns, allowances, and discounts; 
3.  Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 U.S.C. Section 1563(a)(1), between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 U.S.C. Section 1563(a)(2), or between or among wholly owned partnerships or other wholly owned entities; 
4.  Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent; 
5.  Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds, received by a non-profit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article if such funds constitute eighty (80) percent or more of the organization's receipts; and 
6.  Proceeds from sales to customers outside the state. 
(3)  Location or office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. 
(4)  Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. 
(5)  Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A section 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
(6)  Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple-line business from which the greatest amount of income is derived. 
(7)  Person wherever used in this article, shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, or any other form of business organization. 
(8)  Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. "Practitioners of professions and occupations" shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-43. - Fee structure. 
(a)  A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. 
(b)  A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A section 48-13-9 on those businesses that require an application on an annual basis, and on those businesses who will require an application for the initial registration for the purpose of regulating the business through the use of character checks, or other verification that is necessary to legally permit operation of that business for the current calendar year. Regulatory fees shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fees is on file in the city clerk's office. The following, although not exclusive, is a list of businesses that would be required to pay a regulatory fee: 
(1)  Building and construction contractors, subcontractors and workers. 
(2)  Carnivals. 
(3)  Taxicabs and limousine operators. 
(4)  Tattoo artists. 
(5)  Stables. 
(6)  Shooting galleries and firearm ranges. 
(7)  Scrap metal processors. 
(8)  Pawnbrokers. 
(9)  Food service establishments. 
(10)  Dealers in precious metals. 
(11)  Firearms dealers. 
(12)  Peddlers. 
(13)  Parking lots. 
(14)  Nursing and personal care homes. 
(15)  Newspaper vending boxes. 
(16)  Modeling agencies. 
(17)  Massage parlors. 
(18)  Landfills. 
(19)  Auto and motorcycle racing. 
(20)  Boarding houses. 
(21)  Businesses that provide appearance bonds. 
(22)  Boxing and wrestling promoters. 
(23)  Hotels and motels. 
(24)  Hypnotists. 
(25)  Handwriting analysts. 
(26)  Health clubs, gyms, and spas. 
(27)  Fortunetellers. 
(28)  Amusement center proprietors. 
(c)  An occupation tax shall be levied as the revenue producing component of the fee structure. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 98-6, § 1, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 9-44. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions; nontransferable. 
(a)  Levied. An occupation tax shall be levied based upon the gross receipts of the business or practitioner in combination with the profitability ratio for the type of business, profession, or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from the Statistics of Income Bulletin as published by the United States Internal Revenue Service or successor agencies of the United States. Each type of business shall be assigned to a profit class based on the profitability ratio for that business type. The occupation tax rate levied will be based on the profit class of the dominant line of the business as defined by the Standard Industrial Classification system. Gross receipts shall be defined as set forth in section 9-42(b)(2). The tax rate determined by profitability ratios in combination with gross receipts for each business, trade, profession, or occupation shall be as follows and will be developed and updated annually by the city based on variables of changing budget requirements and gross receipts. A detailed example of calculations used to formulate the occupation tax schedule can be obtained from the city in the form of an Occupation Tax Handbook. 
(b)  Occupation tax schedule. 
Profit class 1 Tax class 1 - .000636 Profit class 2 Tax class 2 - .000954 Profit class 3 Tax class 3 - .001272 Profit class 4 Tax class 4 - .001590 Profit class 5 Tax class 5 - .001908 Profit class 6 Tax class 6 - .002226  
(c)  Restrictions. 
(1)  The city shall not require the payment of more than one occupation tax for each location that a business or practitioner shall have nor shall the city require that a business pay an occupation tax for more than one hundred (100) percent of the gross receipts. 
(2)  The city shall not require an occupation tax on those receipts that were taxed by an occupation tax in other localities or states. 
(3)  The city shall not require an occupation tax from those real estate brokers, agents, or companies whose offices are located outside the city and sell property inside the limits of the city. 
(4)  Occupation tax shall not be levied in any manner except as described in this section. 
(5)  Effective January 1, 2001, to December 31, 2001, the maximum annual occupation tax shall be twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) to encourage future economic growth within the limits of the city. Gross receipts in conjunction with the profitability class shall determine the maximum occupation tax to be levied. Effective January 1, 2002, and thereafter, the maximum annual occupation tax shall be thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00). 
(d)  Nontransferable. Occupation tax certificates shall not be transferable and a transfer of ownership shall be considered in the same light as the termination of the business and the establishment of a new business; therefore, a new occupation tax certificate shall be required for the new owner of the business. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 2000-12, § 1, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 9-45. - Each line of business to be identified on occupation tax certificate. 
    The occupation tax certificate for each business registered by the city shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the revenue collection division and that line of business being imprinted by the revenue collection division upon the occupation tax certificate. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-46. - The number of businesses considered operating in city. 
    Where a person conducts business at more than one store or place, each store or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of assessment of an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-47. - Professionals as classified in O.C.G.A 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18). 
    Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A section 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on gross receipts in combination with the profitability ratios as provided in section 9-44; or 
(2)  A fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner electing to pay four hundred dollars ($400.00) per practitioner shall not be required to provide information to the city relating to the gross receipts of the practitioner. The following is a list of such practitioners or professionals subject to these conditions: 
a.  Lawyers. 
b.  Physicians licensed under OCGA, Title 34, Chapter 43. 
c.  Osteopaths licensed under OCGA, Title 34, Chapter 43. 
d.  Chiropractors. 
e.  Podiatrists. 
f.  Dentists. 
g.  Optometrists. 
h.  Psychologists. 
i.  Veterinarians. 
j.  Landscape architects. 
k.  Land surveyors. 
l.  Practitioners of physiotherapy. 
m.  Public accountants. 
n.  Embalmers. 
o.  Funeral directors. 
p.  Civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers. 
q.  Architects. 
r.  Marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors. 
This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by February 15 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-48. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. 
    Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, shall not be required to obtain an occupation tax certificate, or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-49. - Purpose of tax. 
    The tax levied herein is for revenue purpose only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-50. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. 
(a)  Each such occupation tax shall be for the calendar year 1996 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Said registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by February 15 of each year, and if delinquent shall be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in section 9-56 of this article. On any new profession, trade or calling begun in Union City in 1996 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business and a ten (10) percent penalty imposed. In addition, the business is liable for interest on the unpaid estimated business tax, or portion thereof, computed at a rate of eighteen (18) percent annually. The tax registration herein provided for shall be issued by the revenue collection officer and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after said registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact in Union City any kind of profession, trade, or calling in this article specified without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall, upon conviction by the municipal court judge, be punished by a fine not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00), or imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days, either or both in the discretion of the municipal court judge. 
(b)  In addition to the above remedies, the revenue collection officer may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
(c)  The revenue collection officer shall have the power and authorization to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the city and the state or the Constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. These rules and regulations shall become effective upon adoption by the mayor and council. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything in this code section to the contrary, the criminal sanctions imposed due to the delinquent payment by the payor of the occupation tax, shall not be enforceable against members of the legal profession. Timely payment of the occupation tax is required subject to the penalty as specified in section 9-56, however, no fines and/or imprisonment shall be levied against members of the State Bar of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 97-09, 11-18-97) 
Sec. 9-51. - Allocation of gross receipts of business with multiple intra or interstate locations. 
    For those businesses who have multiple locations inside and outside of the city, the gross receipts used to determine the occupational tax assessed will be those gross receipts attributed to each Union City location. In the case where the dollar amount of gross receipts attributed locally cannot be determined in those businesses with multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in Union City and elsewhere and allotted to those locations. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide to the city the following: 
(1)  Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and 
(2)  Information relating to the allocation of the business's or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. 
Where the business has locations outside the city and taxation is levied for a criterion other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-52. - Exemption on grounds that business operated for charitable purpose; religious and charitable soliciting. 
(a)  No business on which an occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from said tax on the grounds that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless such business provides proof of tax-exempt status within the meaning of section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code as such code presently exists or is hereinafter amended. 
(b)  Any person desiring to solicit or canvass, or call from house to house, within the city for the purpose of raising funds or seeking donations for any religious, charitable, political or eleemosynary organization shall register with and obtain a written permit from the city. 
(c)  Any person desiring a permit to canvass, or to call from house to house, within the city shall file, on a form to be supplied by the city, an application stating the following: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Permanent home address; 
(3)  Name and address of employer, firm, corporation, organization or candidate represented; 
(4)  Names and addresses of all persons assisting in the soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house in the city; and 
(5)  Nature of any merchandise, wares, goods, or any similar items to be sold or offered for sale or given away in conjunction with the soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house in the city. 
(d)  Any person who wishes to solicit on private property must submit written permission from the owner of such property concurrently with the application for a permit. 
(e)  Upon proper registration with the city, a written permit shall be issued which will be valid for a period of ninety (90) days from the date of issuance. In addition, identity cards shall be issued which must be carried by all persons while engaged in soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house in the city. 
(f)  Soliciting or canvassing or calling from house to house within the city shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  All soliciting and canvassing or calling from house to house shall only occur between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time or 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Daylight Saving Time. 
(2)  The number of solicitors or canvassers or callers from house to house from any single firm, corporation, organization or candidate shall not exceed twenty-five (25) in number. 
(3)  Immediately prior to any solicitation of funds within the city, each solicitor, canvasser or caller shall present his identity card, issued by the city, to each person solicited and request each person solicited to read such identity card. Each solicitor, canvasser or caller must inform each person solicited in clear language of the nature and purpose of the solicitation and the name and home or national office or headquarters of the firm, corporation, organization or candidate represented. Further, each solicitor, canvasser or caller must inform each person solicited as to any merchandise, wares, goods or any similar items given by such solicitor, canvasser or caller prior to such acceptance by each person solicited. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for a solicitor, canvasser or caller to do any of the following: 
(1)  Falsely represent, directly or by implication, that funds being solicited are on behalf of any person, firm, corporation, association or organization other than such registered with the city. 
(2)  To solicit at any residence, address, apartment complex, shopping mall, or other private properties within the city, other than areas open to public parking without obtaining prior written permission from the occupant or property owner. 
(3)  To remain on private premises after being asked to leave, or to continue solicitation after being refused; such action shall constitute harassment. 
(h)  Any nonprofit organization conducting annual fundraisings or annual sales within the city shall not be required to obtain identity cards from the city, nor shall the numbers of such solicitors, canvassers or callers be restricted, provided such annual fundraisings or annual sales do not exceed seven (7) days per year. However, such nonprofit organization must comply with all other provisions contained in this section. 
(i)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Provided further, that each separate violation, and each day of any continuing violation, shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-53. - Evidence of state licensure required if applicable; license to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed under Title 43 of the state license examining boards shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration is issued. 
(b)  Each person who is subject to a city registration and also is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-54. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
(a)  Any business which is required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(b)  Any business which is required to submit an annual application for continuance of that business shall do so before the registration is issued. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 9-55. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
    All persons subject to the occupation tax provided in this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for said business prescribed in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in Union City shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same and any person transacting, or offering to transact in Union City, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained said registration shall be subject to penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 95-8, § 1, 12-19-95)
