Sec. 12-102. - Permits for filming. 
(a)  Any producer that wishes to perform filming must first obtain a filming permit. No filming permit is required unless the entertainment industry work is performed on public property. 
(b)  Filming permits shall be issued by the city manager. Permits shall be issued to the producer. 
(c)  A permit will specify the filming that may occur at a particular location at a particular time. The permit will authorize element(s) to be performed as part of the filming provided that the elements have been approved by the department of purview. After receiving a permit, a producer may request modifications to the permit as described in section 12-107(a) below. 
(d)  Where the filming application includes a request to close a city street, lane and/or sidewalk, the request shall be evaluated under and the closure must comply with all applicable state or local laws regarding closing of or encroachments on city streets, lanes and/or sidewalks. 
(e)  A producer that receives a permit is responsible for knowing and complying with all other laws, including other ordinances and regulations that establish prerequisites, authorizations and other required permissions applicable to the filming. 
(f)  Where permitted filming includes advertising signs or other displays of commercial speech, the signs and/or displays must be removed upon the expiration of the permit. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other part of this Code, any producer that performs filming without receiving a permit, violates the material terms of a permit, or is otherwise in violation of this entertainment filming ordinance, shall be subject to the provisions of section 1-17 of the Code. 
(h)  While it is the intent of the city to honor each permit, the issuance of such permit shall not grant the producer a constitutionally protected property interest. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-103. - Exemption from filming permit requirement-First amendment activity. 
    The following types of filming are exempt from the permitting requirement of section 12-103(1) [12-102(a)] above. This provision does not exempt a producer from complying with other applicable Code provisions, laws, ordinances or regulations that require elements or other activities included in the filming to be permitted or approved by the appropriate governmental entity. 
(1)  Filming associated with any permitted or unpermitted rally, protest or demonstration, except when the same is staged for the sole purpose of being included in the filming's final product. 
(2)  Filming associated with an outdoor event that is authorized by a city-issued outdoor event permit, except when the same is staged for the sole purpose of being included in the filming's final product. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-104. - Filming elements. 
(a)  An applicant shall indicate on the application each of the elements listed below that will be included in the filming. 
(b)  The final decision of whether to allow the element shall be made by the department of purview after consultation with the city manager, and communicated to the applicant by the city manager. Prior to denying permission to perform an element, representatives of the department of purview and city manager shall consult with the producer in an attempt to find alternative ways to accommodate the producer's filming needs. 
(c)  This section applies to the activities listed below only when they occur on public property. Where the element requires approval from an additional governmental jurisdiction, the producer must obtain that approval as well. 
(d)  The elements are as follows: 
(1)  Night-time filming with the use of outdoor lighting where a residence exists within one hundred fifty (150) feet from the location of an outdoor light; 
(2)  Filming in buildings that are owned by the city and not leased to a third party, or in buildings of which the city is a lessee; 
(3)  Use of a temporary structure that requires permitting by the office of community development and/or the Union City Fire Department; 
(4)  Use of intellectual property belonging to the city; 
(5)  Closure of a street, lane and/or sidewalk; 
(6)  Use of pyrotechnics or other explosives; 
(7)  Smoke effects, water effects, or flame effects; 
(8)  Display of real or artificial fire arms, grenades, or other weapons that would cause the public to fear violence; 
(9)  Vehicle chases and/or vehicle crashes: 
(10)  Dangerous stunts that have a reasonable likelihood of causing substantial personal injury; 
(11)  Use of large or any other equipment that has a reasonable likelihood of causing damage to public property; 
(12)  Filming in a city park; and 
(13)  Use of wild animals controlled under federal, state, or county law and/or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-105. - Processing of permit applications. 
    A producer that wishes to perform filming must submit to the city manager a completed application and the application fee set forth in code section 12-109 below. Where the producer is an organization, corporation or other entity, the application must be signed and submitted by an individual authorized to bind the producer. The city manager will process the application and make permit determinations in accordance with this article V. 
(1)  The application shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  The filming project name; 
b.  The name and contact information of the applicant, including postal address, email address, and telephone number; 
c.  A valid photo identification of the applicant; 
d.  The name and contact information of the producer (if the applicant is not the producer); 
e.  The dates, times and locations of the filming for which a permit is being requested, and a general description of the filming activity that will occur at each location; 
f.  A description of any elements that may be performed during the filming, including the dates, times and locations of each; 
g.  A description of any aspects of the filming, other than the elements, that may require city services; 
h.  A description of any assistance the producer may need from the city, and/or concerns that the producer wants the city to be aware of; 
i.  A synopsis of the film project; and 
j.  Where the producer is a student, an official letter or document from her/his school confirming that s/he is currently enrolled there. In addition, the student must appear in person at the city and present her/his current student identification card and a valid driver's license. Where the student does not have a driver's license, s/he may present a different form of identification that includes her/his photo. 
(2)  When more than one (1) application is received for filming at substantially the same place and time, and the city manager reasonably determines that the filmings cannot logistically and/or safely occur together, the earlier or earliest of the applications that is received by the city manager in a substantially completed form, which includes submission of the requisite application fee, shall be given priority as to the time and place requested. The city manager shall make reasonable efforts to consult with the other applicant(s) in an attempt to find alternative times and/or locations that are acceptable. 
(3)  There is no deadline by which a filming permit application must be submitted to the city manager; however, where a filming permit application includes a request for a street closure, the street closure portion of the application will not be approved unless it is received at least five (5) business days prior to the closure. In any event, if the city manager determines that the timeframe for which a filming permit is needed does not provide a reasonable time for the city to process the application, the city manager shall have discretion to reject the application immediately upon receipt. 
(4)  The city manager and the departments of purview shall compile and maintain rules and guidelines applicable to the use of public property for filming, including the elements that are part of the filming, and shall apply those rules and guidelines equally regardless of the subject matter of the filming and/or the content of the speech therein. 
(5)  In the event that permission to perform an element is denied pursuant to subsection (2) above, the city manager will process the remainder of the permit and grant all other aspects of the filming for which the requirements have been met. 
(6)  The city manager may deny an application only if he or she reasonably determines that one (1) or more of the below-listed conditions exists. Prior to denial, the city manager shall make reasonable efforts to consult with the producer in an attempt to resolve issues of concern and/or find alternative ways to accommodate the producer's filming needs, as described in sections 12-106(g), (h), (i) and (j) below. 
a.  The filming poses an unreasonable risk of personal injury or property damage to people or property not associated with the filming; 
b.  The filming poses an unreasonable risk of damage to public property that could not be quickly and/or fully remediated; 
c.  The date and time requested for a particular filming location conflicts with previously-issued permits or permissions for filming, outdoor events, or other activities; 
d.  Use of the filming location, or use of the location during the date or time requested, would unreasonably interfere with the operation of city functions; 
e.  Use of the filming location or the proposed activity at the location would violate a law, ordinance, statute or regulation, regardless of whether the illegal activity is part of the message or content of the filming. A permit shall not be denied based upon simulation of an illegal activity where the actual illegal activity is not being performed; 
f.  The producer owes an outstanding debt to the city; 
g.  The producer previously caused significant damage to public property and, at the time of submitting the application under consideration, failed to adequately repair the damage or pay in full the city's invoice for damage repair and restoration services; 
h.  The producer previously violated this entertainment filming ordinance on two (2) or more occasions, including without limitation by violating a material condition and/or restriction of a permit; 
i.  On two (2) or more occasions, the producer's entertainment industry work in the city violated a city ordinance or other applicable law; 
j.  The applicant made a material misrepresentation or gave incorrect material information on the application; or 
k.  The city manager determines that the filming would be detrimental to the best interests of the city. 
(7)  Prior to denying an application, if the city manager determines that the requested filming includes one (1) or more of the conditions described in subsections (6)a., b., c., or d. above, the city manager shall employ reasonable efforts to identify alternative filming locations, times and/or dates that eliminate the unacceptable condition(s) and that are mutually acceptable to the producer and the city. The producer shall modify the application to incorporate any agreed-upon alternatives. 
(8)  Prior to denying an application, if the city manager determines that the requested filming or related activity creates a violation as described in subsection (6)c. above, the city manager shall allow the producer to revise the application so that the filming activities comply with applicable law. 
(9)  Prior to denying an application pursuant to subsections (6)f. or g. above, the city manager shall notify the producer of the potential denial and allow her/him to remedy the conditions described in those subsections. The city manager shall process the application after such repair, restoration or payment is complete, and may require the producer to obtain a refundable sanitation bond for the filming permit in an amount equivalent to the cost of the repair, restoration or debt. 
(10)  Prior to denying an application pursuant to subsections (6)h., i. or j. above, the city manager shall provide the applicant an opportunity to present documents or other evidence that refutes the city manager's finding of previous permit violations, of previous violations of the law, or of misrepresentation or misinformation on the application, as applicable. 
(11)  Where the city manager has complied with subsections (7), (8), (9) and/or (10) above and reasonably determines that one (1) or more of the conditions set forth in subsection (6) continues to exist and that the application should therefore be denied, the city manager shall issue a written communication to the applicant that includes a detailed explanation for the denial. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude the city manager from also notifying the applicant orally. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-106. - Modification, suspension or cancellation of a permit. 
(a)  After receiving a permit, the producer may request a material modification of the permit at any time by submitting to the city manager a change request and change fee as set forth in Code section 12-109. The city manager's ability to process the change request shall be determined pursuant to the provisions established for processing applications, as set forth in sections 12-105(2) and (3) above. The city manager's decision of whether to grant or deny the modification request shall be determined as set forth in sections 12-105(4) through 12-105(11). Submission of a change request will not impact the validity of the permit already issued, except upon written request of the producer. 
(b)  Where a producer has obtained a permit and abides by the material requirements thereof, the permit shall prevent the city's stoppage of activities that are authorized by the permit, except as otherwise set forth in subsection (c) below or as a result of applicable law. 
(c)  In the event that the Union City Police Department, Union City Fire Department and/or other department of purview identifies a substantial public health or safety risk arising from or caused by the filming, and the producer is in material compliance with the permit, the following shall occur: 
(1)  Where the substantial risk is identified prior to the commencement of the filming, the city manager and applicable department of purview shall employ reasonable efforts to consult with the producer and identify permit changes that are mutually acceptable to the producer and the city, and that remedy the health/safety issue(s). Where such efforts are unsuccessful, the city manager shall modify the permit in a manner that minimizes disruption of the filming as determined at the city manager's reasonable discretion, and that eliminates the substantial risk as reasonably determined by the department of purview. 
(2)  Where the substantial risk is not imminent and is identified after the commencement of the filming, the city manager and applicable department of purview shall employ reasonable efforts to consult with the producer and identify permit changes that are mutually acceptable to the producer and the city, and that remedy the health/safety issue(s). Where such efforts are unsuccessful, the city manager shall modify the permit in a manner that minimizes disruption of the filming as determined at the city manager's reasonable discretion, and that eliminates the substantial risk as reasonably determined by the department of purview. 
(3)  Where the substantial risk is imminent as reasonably determined by the department of purview and is identified after the commencement of filming, said department may place a stop work order on the filming if it finds that the order will likely alleviate the substantial risk. The stop work order may be issued without advance notice where the department of purview deems that a delay of the order will jeopardize public health and safety, and shall be lifted as quickly as possible after the risk is eliminated. The department of purview shall notify the city manager of the stop work order within two (2) hours of its issuance. The city manager and applicable department of purview shall employ reasonable efforts to consult with the producer and identify permit changes that are mutually acceptable to the producer and the city, that will minimize the length and impact of the stop work order as decided by the producer, and that remedy the health/safety issue(s) as determined by the department of purview. 
(4)  Changes made to the permit pursuant to this subsection (c) shall not require payment of a change fee. 
(d)  Where the city manager, or a department of purview in consultation with the city manager, determines that the producer is violating material term(s) of the permit, the city manager shall decide the appropriate remedial actions after consulting with the department of purview and the producer. If the city manager and/or department of purview finds that a substantial public health or safety risk is arising from or caused by the material violation, the department of purview in consultation with the city manager may place an immediate stop work order on the filming without prior notice to the producer, and consultation with the producer shall occur after the work stoppage. The consultation between the city manager, department of purview and producer shall evaluate the nature and severity of the violation, whether the violation was intentional, whether permit modifications should be made, whether the stop work order should be lifted (where applicable), and what other actions should be taken (if any). Where the violation creates a substantial public health and/or safety risk, the remedial actions decided by the city manager will not be deemed final until the department of purview reviews the remedial actions and confirms that they will eliminate the health and safety risks. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-107. - Responsibilities of a producer once a permit is obtained. 
(a)  A producer or producer's designee must have the permit on site at the time and location of the filming, and must also have on site any other permits required for that location by the city manager or any other governmental agency. 
(b)  A producer must confine filming to the locations, times, guidelines and conditions specified in the permit and must abide by all other material terms of the permit. 
(c)  Permits are not transferable. 
(d)  A producer must clean and repair the filming location, and restore it to the condition it was in immediately prior to the filming, unless otherwise agreed upon in writing by the city manager and the producer. The city manager will inspect the filming location after the filming is completed to ascertain whether this requirement has been met. Where a producer fails to fulfill this requirement, the city manager will bill the producer for the cleaning, repair and/or restoration costs borne by the city, and the producer must pay the invoice in full within thirty (30) days of receipt. 
(e)  Permits shall require the producer to notify the city manager within three (3) hours or sooner of learning of any emergency event regarding or arising from the filming that involves the media, the police or fire departments or emergency medical services. 
(f)  A producer is responsible for: (a) knowing and complying with all city ordinances and other laws applicable to the filming and to the other activities arising from the producer's permit; and (b) requiring and using commercially reasonable efforts to enforce the requirement that any person working for or at the direction of the producer (including without limitation contractors) complies with all city ordinances and other laws applicable to the filming and to the other activities arising from the permit. 
(g)  The requirements of subsection (f) above shall include without limitation that the producer is responsible for obtaining any and all permissions, licenses or other required authorizations for use of intellectual property, including intellectual property which is on public property but is not owned by the city. 
(h)  Permits must prohibit a producer from acting as a representative or agent of the city, and from indicating city endorsement of the filming, except as otherwise agreed to in writing by the city manager. This provision shall not prohibit the producer's use of the city logo in the filming credits. 
(i)  The city manager shall require that notification be given to residents and businesses within a three-block radius of a location for which a filming permit has been issued. The city manager may provide the notification, may require the producer to provide the notification, or may utilize a different mechanism for providing notification. The notification must state that a filming permit has been issued, and must include the date(s), time(s), location(s) and activities that are authorized by the permit. Additionally, the city manager shall require that notification be given to the mayor and council for the city. The city manager shall determine the most effective means and timing of notification based upon factors such as the type of impact that the filming will have on the neighborhood, the time between receipt of the application and commencement of the filming, the producer's budget and previous communications from a neighborhood regarding notification preferences. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-108. - Other permit requirements. 
    After a permit has been approved by the city manager, it will be issued once the following have occurred: 
(1)  The producer signs an indemnification provision on the permit whereby the producer agrees to indemnify the city and its officials and employees from all claims, losses and expenses, including attorneys' fees and costs, that may arise from the permit and any of the activities performed pursuant to the permit by, on behalf of, or at the direction of the producer, except to the extent that that claims, losses and/or expenses are caused by the negligence or intentional misconduct of the city, its officials and/or employees; 
(2)  The producer signs a provision agreeing to comply with all applicable environmental laws, including an agreement not to allow legally-prohibited contaminants from entering the sewage and stormwater drainage systems serving the area where the filming will occur. The producer must sign a separate indemnification clause, such as the one (1) described in subsection (1) immediately above, that pertains specifically to environmental breaches and includes without limitation the fines and clean-up costs associated therewith; 
(3)  The producer obtains insurance coverage in an amount determined by the city's risk manager, covers the city as an additional insured on the policy, and provides proof of the coverage in a manner established by the city's risk manager. The city shall be listed as an additional insured on any insurance policy obtained pursuant to this section; and 
(4)  The producer pays the permit fee and any other applicable fees set forth in section 12-109 below. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Sec. 12-109. - Fee schedule. 
    The city manager shall collect all applicable fees arising pursuant to this article. These fees are set forth below in this section 12-109, and in other sections of the Code pertaining to the cost of services or goods provided by other city departments. 
(1)  Nonrefundable application fee. A filming permit application must be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount set forth below. A filming permit application shall not be deemed complete until the application fee is received by the city manager. 
a.  One hundred dollars ($100.00), except for students. 
b.  Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for students. 
(2)  Filming permit fee. A filming permit authorizes all filming for a particular filming project during a calendar month, regardless of the number of filming locations. A filming permit is valid through the last day of the calendar month and may be renewed for additional calendar months. 
a.  Standard permit fee. The following fees apply when the completed filming permit application is submitted to the city manager more than three (3) business days prior to the effective date of the permit: 
1.  Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for original filming permit, except for students. 
2.  Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each renewal filming permit, except for students. 
3.  One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for students, valid for length of filming project. Monthly renewals not required. 
b.  Rush permit fee. Where a completed filming permit application is submitted to the city manager three (3) or fewer business days prior to the effective date of the permit, the producer must pay the standard permit fee plus the rush fee set forth below in this subsection. Additionally, where a producer submits an application more than three (3) business days prior to the effective date of the permit, the producer voluntarily may pay the standard permit fee plus the rush fee in order to have the application processed within three (3) or fewer business days. 
1.  Three hundred dollars ($300.00), except for students. 
2.  One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for students. 
c.  Material changes to filming permit. 
1.  There is no charge for modifying a filming permit where the city manager reasonably determines that the modification is not material. For purposes of this article, "material" means that processing the requested change will require an expenditure of city staff time or services that is more than de minimus. 
2.  There is no charge for a material change to a filming permit where a completed change request is submitted to the city manager more than three (3) business days prior to the effective date of the permit. Where a material change is requested after the permit has taken effect, there will be no charge if the completed change request is submitted to the city manager more than three (3) business days prior to the implementation of the requested change. 
3.  Where a change request for a material change is submitted to the city manager three (3) or fewer business days prior to the effective date of the permit or the implementation date of the change, as described in subsection (2)c.2. above, the producer must pay the rush change fee set forth below in this subsection. Additionally, where a producer submits a change request more than three (3) business days prior to the implementation of the requested change, the producer voluntarily may pay the rush fee in order to have the change request processed within three (3) or fewer business days: 
(i)  Three hundred dollars ($300.00), except for students. 
(ii)  One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for students. 
d.  Cancellation fee. 
1.  Except as set forth in subsections (2)d.2. and (2)d.3. below, a filming permit fee is nonrefundable. 
2.  Where the producer submits a change request to the city manager and the change results in cancellation of a filming permit for a particular calendar month, the producer may utilize the filming permit fee for the cancelled month to purchase a new filming permit for the same project for a different calendar month. Regardless of whether a new filming permit fee is owed, the city manager shall determine whether a rush fee is applicable based upon the timing of the change request and the standards set forth in subsection (2)c. above. 
3.  A filming permit fee is refundable if cancellation is required because of extraordinary circumstances for which the producer is not responsible and which are not within the producer's control. Inclement weather, except for declared states of emergency, and common illness shall not be deemed extraordinary circumstances. 
(3)  Traffic control plans. 
a.  Entertainment industry work performed at certain locations will require a traffic control plan. The city manager is authorized but not required to offer the service of preparing traffic control plans associated with entertainment industry work. The cost of having the city manager prepare a traffic control plan is as follows: 
1.  For non-students: 
(i)  Traffic control plan for lane and/or sidewalk closure(s) only: one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(ii)  Traffic control plan for street closure(s) only: two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(iii)  Traffic control plan for street closure(s) plus lane and/or sidewalk closure(s) (where the lane and/or sidewalk is not part of or abutting the street being closed): three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
2.  For students: Any type of traffic control plan: twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
b.  The UCPD preparation of a traffic control plan will include submitting the plan to the Union City Public Services Department for review and to the office of transportation for approval, and editing the plan as needed to meet the requirements. 
c.  The producer is not required to have the UCPD prepare the traffic control plan, and there will be no penalty against or differential treatment of any producer who has the plan created by a person or entity other than the UCPD. 
(6)  Street closures permits-Minimum notice. A full street closure will not be permitted unless the application or change request is submitted at least five (5) business days prior to the closure. Rush fees may not be utilized for full street closure requests. 
(7)  Street or sidewalk closures-Fees. No street or sidewalk closure shall be permitted unless the applicant has paid the appropriate fee according to a schedule of fees adopted by the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 12-20-16) 
Secs. 12-110-12-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FOOD TRUCK VENDING ON PUBLIC PROPERTY 

Sec. 12-150. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City-sponsored special events shall mean any activity of the city or sponsored by the city having as its purpose entertainment, recreation, and/or education which: 
(1)  Takes place on public property or in public space; or 
(2)  Takes place on private property, but requires special public services. 
    Special events include, but are not limited to, fairs, tours, grand opening celebrations, races, parades, marches, rallies, assemblies, festivals, concerts, holiday celebrations, bicycle runs, and block parties. Private social gatherings which will make no use of city streets other than for lawful parking are not included. Garage sales, lawn sales, rummage sales, flea market sales, or any similar casual sale of tangible personal property are not included. 
    Designated food truck area means the geographic area supporting the identified city-sponsored special event designated under this article in section 12-154 wherein vending operations may be conducted from a food truck by a vendor holding a valid food truck vending permit. 
    Food truck means a licensed, motorized vehicle or mobile food unit that is licensed by the Georgia State Department of Motor Vehicles and the Georgia Department of Agriculture (where necessary to comply with O.C.G.A. § 26-2-410 et seq. A food truck is a temporarily located unit in an area where food items are to be sold to the general public. 
    Food truck vending permit means a permit issued by the city authorizing vending operations from a food truck. It shall consist of a photo identification card which contains the vendor's name, photograph, food truck location(s) and time period for which such permit is valid. 
    Items permissible for sale means food items which may be dispensed for public consumption pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Fulton County Health Department, but are limited to non-alcoholic pre-packaged beverages; pre-packaged food; prepared food; and prepared non-alcoholic beverages. Items permissible for sale shall not include any tobacco products. 
    Moral turpitude means the act or behavior of baseness, vileness or the depravity in private and social duties which people owe to their fellow people, or to society in general, contrary to accepted and customary rule of right and duty between person and person; and/or the act or behavior that gravely violates moral sentiment or accepted moral standards of community and is a morally suitable quality held to be present in some criminal offenses as distinguished from others. 
    Operating area means the food truck and the parameters around the food truck within which all vending operations are conducted and any appurtenances necessary thereto are located. 
    Permit holder means any person who holds a food truck vending permit. 
    Public property and public space both mean, for the purpose of this article, any property owned by the city within street rights-of-way, including any parking area, roadways and sidewalks, but excluding city-owned parks. 
    Public property vending means vending activity on public property under the jurisdiction of the city. Public property vending shall be prohibited outside of those areas that are designated food truck areas. 
    Vendor means any person who owns, operates or manages a business that uses or applies for a food truck vending permit. 
    Vending operations include all activity necessary to and arising from the business of selling or causing to be sold any items permissible for sale to the general public from a food truck. This shall include but not be limited to unloading and set up activities in preparation of vending, loading and break-down activities necessary to conclude vending activity, all vending of any items permissible for sale and any other related activity. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-151. - Purpose, intent and applicability. 
(a)  Food truck vending operations on public property in the city shall be subject to regulation as set forth herein and as required by all other state and federal law. Food truck vending operations conducted on public property without a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be unlawful and subject to punishment. 
(b)  It is the intent of the mayor and council in enacting this article to: 
(1)  Serve and protect the health, safety and welfare of the general public by requiring food truck vendors ensure residents and customers a minimum level of cleanliness, quality and safety in the course of their operations; and 
(2)  Establish a uniform set of rules and regulations which are fair and equitable to each food truck vendor as well as residents and customers; and 
(3)  Provide economic development opportunities for small entrepreneurs in the city; and 
(4)  Promote stability to individual food truck vendors enabling them to enrich the city with an array of dietary options and become assets to public security. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-152. - Vending operational rules. 
    Food truck vending from public property shall at all times remain in compliance with all of the following standards: 
(1)  The food truck may only utilize public property for vending operations within the area defined in section 12-154 of this article. 
(2)  Vending operations shall only be conducted between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. On Sunday, vending operations shall only be conducted from 12:00 p.m. until 11:00 p.m. 
(3)  Amplified sound or sound equipment requires separate permitting and must comply with the pertinent provisions of the Union City Code of Ordinances at section 10-20. 
(4)  Signage: 
a.  Sandwich board signage must be located within the operating area of the food truck, as defined herein. Sandwich board signage shall be permitted under the following conditions: 
1.  For so long as the food truck is engaged in vending operations; 
2.  Where the aggregate square footage of both sides of the sign does not exceed sixteen (16) square feet; and 
3.  When it is properly permitted and/or otherwise compliant with the sign ordinance, article IX of the Union City Code of Ordinances. 
b.  Wall signage affixed safely to the food truck is allowed without a permit. 
(5)  Vendors may offer to sale only items permissible for sale, as defined herein. 
(6)  All vendors shall display their food truck vending permit and any other required permits in a conspicuous location within the operating area of the food truck. 
(7)  All vendors must maintain an auditable point-of-sale system to track and report sales revenue and appropriate taxation. 
(8)  Vending operations may not obstruct vehicular traffic flow. 
(9)  Vending, including but not limited to the provision of tables and/or chairs, may not exceed the area approved for operation by the food truck vending permit. 
(10)  Food trucks shall not be left unattended nor shall they be stored at any time in any designated food truck area when vending operations are not underway or during any restricted hours of operation. 
(11)  In designated food truck areas, food trucks may only serve customers from the side of the truck facing the sidewalk. Food trucks are prohibited from operating with their trucks open to the roadway. 
(12)  Any person engaged in vending from a food truck is prohibited from conducting any business whatsoever with any patron or customer who is situated in a motor vehicle. 
(13)  All food trucks must be positioned to allow five (5) feet of unobstructed space for pedestrians on all sidewalks, pedestrian paths and other locations intended primarily for pedestrian travel. 
(14)  Littering. All vendors engaged in the sale of items permissible for sale under this article shall affix to their food truck or shall locate directly outside of the food truck, a receptacle for trash. This receptacle shall be maintained and emptied regularly and shall be marked as being for trash. Vendors are responsible for the removal of trash, litter, garbage, and debris within a twenty-five-foot radius surrounding their food truck. Disposal of all trash, litter, garbage, and debris shall be accomplished by the food truck vendor in such a way as it conforms to the litter control ordinance of Union City, article IV of the Union City Code of Ordinances. 
(15)  Designated food truck areas shall be open for use to vendors permitted under this article on a first come first serve basis. If demand for space in the designated food truck area exceeds the availability, the city may utilize a lottery system to award food truck vending permits in the future. 
(16)  Food trucks shall not be engaged in any vending operations within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant nor within five (5) feet of a utility box, handicapped ramp, or emergency call box. 
(17)  Food trucks shall not be engaged in any vending operations within six hundred (600) feet of the closest property line of any public or private elementary, middle, or high school. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-153. - Permits and licenses. 
    A food truck vending permit and an occupational tax permit are required. 
(1)  No public property vending shall occur without a food truck vending permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(2)  Public property vending shall be permitted only in the designated food truck area(s) stated on the food truck vending permit. 
(3)  No person shall engage in the business or trade of vending without first obtaining an occupational tax certificate. 
(4)  Food truck vending permits are nontransferable. 
(5)  A food truck vending permit must be displayed in clear view in the operating area of the food truck at all times. All other permits required to remain compliant under this article shall be available for inspection at all times. No food truck vending permit shall be issued without proof of a valid insurance policy. Said insurance shall be through an insurance carrier that is authorized and eligible to do business in the State of Georgia. The policy will cover all costs of any damage to public property and right-of-way and for any damages for which the city might incur liability due to property damage or personal injury arising out of the use of the public property and right-of-way for vending operations. The minimum liability limit of the policy shall be one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). The city shall be listed as an additional insured and the policy shall provide that it cannot terminate or be cancelled prior to the expiration date without thirty (30) days' written notice to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-154. - Locations. 
    Food truck vending operations shall be conducted on public property and/or in public space only during city-sponsored special events where such city-sponsored special events are held. The events where food truck vending operations may occur are listed on the schedule of city-sponsored special events which is kept on file in the office of the city clerk. Food truck vending operations shall be permitted only in designated food truck areas during these events. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17; Ord. No. 2018-02 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
Sec. 12-155. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a food truck vending permit shall be submitted to the city community development department with a non-refundable application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), annually. Each applicant must apply in person and complete an application form. Application forms shall be made available by the community development department. 
(b)  Food truck vending permit fees are due and payable by money order, certified check or cashier's check if and when an application is approved. The application shall, at a minimum, contain the following information: 
(1)  Applicant's name and current address; 
(2)  Applicant's social security number; 
(3)  Proposed location of the food truck; 
(4)  City occupational tax certificate; 
(5)  A dimensional drawing that clearly shows the footprint of the food truck and all required operating area, including but not limited to location and area required for any proposed signage, tables, chairs, or litter receptacle; 
(6)  The times during which the vending operations are proposed to occur; 
(7)  Georgia Department of Revenue retail identification tax number; 
(8)  A copy of a state-issued driver's license; 
(9)  Proof of current auto and general liability insurance; 
(10)  Make, model and license plate number of the food truck; 
(11)  A copy of the approved permit from the Fulton County Health Department; 
(12)  An agreement to hold the city, its officers, elected officials, and employees harmless and indemnify them for any loss, liability, damage and costs and expenses arising from operations; and 
(13)  A general description of the items permissible for sale which are proposed to be sold or offered for sale. 
(c)  All applicants shall furnish all data, information and records requested of them within thirty (30) days from the date of request. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-156. - Term and renewal of permits. 
    A food truck vending permit will be issued for a one-year period of time. All food truck vending permits are required to be renewed annually on or before December 31. All annual permit fees are due and payable at the time of renewal. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-157. - Annual fees. 
    The annual permit fee for a food truck vending permit shall be one-hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-158. - Change of address. 
    Any person moving from one (1) location to another shall notify the community development department of the move and the new address. This notice shall be in writing on a form provided by the Community Development Department of Union City. Notification of address change shall be given no later than the day of moving. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-159. - Denials, fines, suspensions, and revocations. 
(a)  No food truck vending permit shall be issued to any person who has been convicted within the five (5) years immediately prior to the filing of an application of any felony or misdemeanor relating to drug possession and related matter; crime of moral turpitude; larceny; fraudulent conveyance; perjury and/or false swearing, or subornation of perjury. Any conviction for dealing and/or trafficking in illegal drugs will automatically disqualify an applicant. 
(b)  A food truck vending permit can be denied, revoked or suspended at any time for any of the following: 
(1)  Failure to maintain initial eligibility qualifications; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statements contained in the application; 
(3)  Failure to furnish any and all documentation requested by either the police department, or the community development department for purposes of an investigation of any application or for the inspection of records within thirty (30) days of such request; 
(4)  The revocation of a food truck vending permit by the county entity that issued said permit shall cause immediate revocation of the city food truck vending permit; 
(5)  The discovery of evidence, at any time, of the improper disposal of liquid waste or grease shall cause a food truck vending permit to be rendered null and void and all public property vending by the vendor will be required to cease immediately; and/or 
(6)  Any failure to comply with any requirement set forth in this article. 
(c)  Any person whose food truck vending permit is revoked may not reapply for a food truck vending permit for one (1) year following the effective date of the revocation. 
(d)  In addition to carrying out all other investigations as may be permitted under this article, the police department and/or the community development department shall investigate any alleged violation of this article upon receipt of a written, sworn complaint by any person who witnesses or becomes aware of a potential violation of this article. Such complaint shall be signed under penalty of perjury, and shall be accompanied by any available supporting evidence. 
(e)  Each day that an offense occurs or continues under this article shall be a separate and distinct violation. The following penalties shall be applicable: 
(1)  A violation within twenty-four (24) months of being issued a food truck vending permit or within twenty-four (24) months of a previous violation, will result in a one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine. 
(2)  A second violation within twenty-four (24) months of being issued a food truck vending permit or within twenty-four (24) months of a previous violation, will result in a fine of no less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and no more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or up to a twelve-month suspension of the permit, or revocation of the permit. 
(3)  A third violation within twenty-four (24) months of being issued a food truck vending permit or within twenty-four (24) months of a previous violation, will result in revocation of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-160. - Public hearing on fine, suspension, revocation, or denial. 
(a)  Any fine, suspension, revocation or denial of a food truck vending permit under section 12-159 hereof, may be appealed by filing a written notice of appeal to the city council within twenty (20) days of the applicant vendor's or current vendor's receipt of the notice described in section 12-160(b). 
(b)  Notice of the denial, suspension, fine, or revocation of a food truck vending permit shall be given in writing. Said notice shall set forth the complaint, the grounds for denial, suspension, fine, or revocation, and the time, date, and place for a hearing on the matter. The notice shall be mailed to the permit holder at least five (5) calendar days prior to the date set for the hearing, by registered or certified mail, to the address shown on the application for the food truck vending permit. The city council shall conduct a hearing at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-161. - City reservation of right to suspend a food truck vending permit. 
(a)  The city reserves the right to require any person that is holding or operating under a food truck vending permit to temporarily cease part or all of the operation, or remove the food truck from the designated food truck area in order to allow for construction, maintenance or repair of any street, curb, gutter, sidewalk, storm drain inlet or any other similar municipal utility. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to temporarily suspend any food truck vending permit to maintain the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to temporarily suspend any food truck vending permit when a street is closed for a special event. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-162. - Vendors selling ice cream or other pre-packaged food and/or non-alcoholic pre-packaged beverages out of motor vehicles. 
    Vendors selling ice cream or other pre-packaged food or non-alcoholic pre-packaged beverages out of motor vehicles, other than food trucks within a designated food truck area, are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 12-163. - Termination or amendment of food truck vending operations on public property. 
    The city council may amend, revise, or terminate this article as it pertains to food trucks and the vending operations thereof on public property at any time. This shall be done by duly enacting an ordinance following a public hearing. Notice of the public hearing shall be published once at least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing. In such circumstance, the city shall retain the entire fee paid for the permit by the permit holder; no refund shall be issued for any food truck vending permit that may become invalid due to the amendment, revision, or termination of food truck vending. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 4-18-17) 
Chapter 13 - TAXATION AND FINANCE[1]
